After several failed attempts to conceive a child of their own, Monica and Chandler discover that they are both [[Infertility|infertile]],{{cite web|url=http://chealth.canoe.com/channel_health_features_details.asp?channel_id=2048&relation_id=109683&health_feature_id=378&article_id=1198 |title=Celebrities and Fertility |date= |accessdate=September 11, 2015 |website=Canoe.ca |publisher=MediResource Inc |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117022311/http://chealth.canoe.com/channel_health_features_details.asp?channel_id=2048&relation_id=109683&health_feature_id=378&article_id=1198 |archivedate=November 17, 2015 |df= }} and ultimately settle upon adoption as an alternative, deciding to adopt the yet-to-be-born child of expectant single mother [[List of Friends characters|Erica]] ([[Anna Faris]]). The couple is very much surprised when Erica gives birth to twins, and name the boy Jack after Monica's father, and the girl Erica after her birth mother. == Development == === Conception and writing === Television writers [[David Crane (producer)|David Crane]] and [[Marta Kauffman]] originally pitched ''Friends'' as a show about "that special time in your life when your friends are your family"{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/news/industry-news/friends-20th-anniversary-oral-history |title=Friends: A 20th Anniversary Oral History |date=September 16, 2014 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=Emmys.com |publisher=Academy of Television Arts & Sciences |last=Keck |first=William |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402144101/http://www.emmys.com/news/industry-news/friends-20th-anniversary-oral-history |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }} to then-[[NBC]] president [[Warren Littlefield]] shortly after their short-lived sitcom ''[[Family Album (1993 TV series)|Family Album]]'' was canceled by [[CBS]]. Inspired by their own experiences as young adults living in [[New York City]], the writers loosely based the six main characters on some of their own friends and family;{{cite web|url=http://thescriptlab.com/features/tales-from-the-trade/1253-interview-marta-kauffman# |title=Interview: Marta Kauffman |date=August 2, 2011 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=The Script Lab |publisher=TSL Media Inc |last=Lusinski |first=Natalia |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328164204/http://thescriptlab.com/features/tales-from-the-trade/1253-interview-marta-kauffman |archivedate=March 28, 2015 |df= }} Monica is based on Kauffman herself. Observing that each main character was originally written as a "one-note stereotype", Jonathan Bernstein of ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' identified Monica as the group's "uptight fun-killer".{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/11110627/Friends-at-20-how-Ross-and-Rachel-started-a-TV-revolution.html |title=Friends at 20: how Ross and Rachel started a TV revolution |date=September 22, 2014 |accessdate=September 17, 2015 |website=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |last=Bernstein |first=Jonathan |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150519040048/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/tvandradio/11110627/Friends-at-20-how-Ross-and-Rachel-started-a-TV-revolution.html |archivedate=May 19, 2015 |df= }} When ''Friends'' first aired, the majority of its earliest episodes revolved around Monica, via whom each character appears to be interconnected; ''Friends'' stars the character's brother, her best friend, her former roommate and her two neighbors socializing in Monica's apartment. In the pilot, Monica is dumped almost immediately after sleeping with her new date Paul on the night of their first date. Monica is tricked into bed with him after Paul lies to her about his [[sex life]], falsely alleging that he has not slept with anyone in the two years since his wife left him.{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/emma-gray/friends-tv-monica-geller-nbc-president-slut-whore-trollop_b_1472477.html |title='Friends'' Monica Geller Was A 'Slut' And A 'Trollop,' According To NBC's Former West Coast President |date=May 2, 2012 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=The Huffington Post |publisher=TheHuffingtonPost.com, Inc |last=Gray |first=Emma |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925125030/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/emma-gray/friends-tv-monica-geller-nbc-president-slut-whore-trollop_b_1472477.html |archivedate=September 25, 2015 |df= }} At first, NBC executives worried that audiences would react to Monica's role unfavorably, thus they decided to survey the [[studio audience]] and ask them whether or not they thought that having Monica sleep with someone on their first date made her character too [[Promiscuity|promiscuous]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/4899445/ns/dateline_nbc-newsmakers/t/friends-creators-share-shows-beginnings/#.Vcq51flbUQI |title='Friends' creators share show's beginnings |date=May 5, 2004 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=NBC News |publisher=NBCNews.com |last=Lauer |first=Matt |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002171335/http://www.nbcnews.com/id/4899445/ns/dateline_nbc-newsmakers/t/friends-creators-share-shows-beginnings/ |archivedate=October 2, 2013 |df= }} [[Don Ohlmeyer]], then-president of NBC's west coast division, was particularly adamant about his stance against Monica's role in the pilot, which he considered "[[casual sex]]",{{cite web |url=http://archive.entertainmentwise.com/news/75121/1/Courteney-Coxs-Friends-Character-Branded-A-Slut-And-A-Trollop |title=Courteney Cox's Friends Character Branded A 'Slut' And 'A Trollop' |date=May 4, 2012 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=Entertainmentwise |publisher=Giant Digital |last=Rajani |first=Deepika |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150927092719/http://archive.entertainmentwise.com/news/75121/1/Courteney-Coxs-Friends-Character-Branded-A-Slut-And-A-Trollop |archivedate=September 27, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} and created a "[[bias|stacked]]" questionnaire asking audience members if they thought Monica was a whore.{{cite web|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2138739/Friends-Monica-Geller-slut-trollop-according-NBC-president.html|title = Friends' Monica Geller was 'a slut' and 'a trollop' according to NBC president|date = May 3, 2012|accessdate = August 12, 2015|website = Daily Mail|publisher = Associated Newspapers Ltd|last = Epstein|first = Emily Anne|archiveurl = https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20120504003941/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2138739/Friends-Monica-Geller-slut-trollop-according-NBC-president.html|archivedate = May 4, 2012|dead-url = no|df = mdy-all}} Kauffman recalled Ohlmeyer specifically expressing that Monica deserved to be dumped, a statement by which the writer was greatly offended,{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/06/09/friends-monica-geller-got-slut-shamed-for-sleeping-with-paul-the-wine-guy-5237711/ |title=Friends’ Monica Geller got slut-shamed for sleeping with Paul the wine guy |date=June 9, 2015 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=Metro |publisher=Associated Newspapers Limited |last=Baillie |first=Katie |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150812061128/http://metro.co.uk/2015/06/09/friends-monica-geller-got-slut-shamed-for-sleeping-with-paul-the-wine-guy-5237711/ |archivedate=August 12, 2015 |df= }} dismissing Ohlmeyer as a [[misogynist]].{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jaimieetkin/former-nbc-president-slut-shamed-monica-over-the-friends-pil#.qeebKvyl2 |title=Former NBC President Slut-Shamed Monica Over The "Friends" Pilot |date=June 5, 2015 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=BuzzFeed |publisher=BuzzFeed Inc |last=Etkin |first=Jaimie |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150822002003/http://www.buzzfeed.com/jaimieetkin/former-nbc-president-slut-shamed-monica-over-the-friends-pil |archivedate=August 22, 2015 |df= }} Ultimately, the results returned in favor of Monica; audiences liked the character nonetheless, and the episode aired unchanged. Early in the series, Monica's apartment is established as one of the show's two primary locations. In the pilot, the apartment number is 5, which was changed to 20 in subsequent episodes after the writers determined that Monica actually lived on a much higher floor.{{cite web|url=http://mentalfloss.com/article/56565/25-things-you-might-not-know-about-friends |title=25 Things You Might Not Know About Friends |date=September 22, 2014 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=Mental Floss |publisher=Mental Floss, Inc |last=Danko |first=Meredith |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150326225914/http://mentalfloss.com/article/56565/25-things-you-might-not-know-about-friends |archivedate=March 26, 2015 |df= }} Season three's "[[The One Where No One's Ready]]" takes place entirely in Monica's apartment because the show's budget was not large enough to accommodate additional sets or guest stars at that time.{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/tabathaleggett/things-you-probably-didnt-know-about-friends#.yoyEqAK7n |title=61 Things You Probably Didn’t Know About "Friends" |date=July 22, 2014 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=BuzzFeed |publisher=BuzzFeed Inc |last=Leggett |first=Tabatha |last2=Edds |first2=Robin |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150316165827/http://www.buzzfeed.com/tabathaleggett/things-you-probably-didnt-know-about-friends |archivedate=March 16, 2015 |df= }} In the series finale, Phoebe certifies that each character shared Monica's apartment at least one point during their lives.{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2014/09/22/19-friends-facts-you-actually-didnt-know-4872196/ |title=As Friends celebrates its 20th anniversary: 19 Friends facts you ACTUALLY really didn’t know |date=September 22, 2014 |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |website=Metro |publisher=Associated Newspapers Limited |last=Stewart |first=Ellen |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150817121928/http://metro.co.uk/2014/09/22/19-friends-facts-you-actually-didnt-know-4872196/ |archivedate=August 17, 2015 |df= }} ==== Relationship with Chandler Bing ==== Andrew Harrison of ''[[The New Republic]]'' believes that the writers deliberately broke up any main character who was approaching a borderline life-changing relationship because "The ones the Friends were really meant to be with were, after all, the other Friends".{{cite web|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/119434/friends-20th-anniversary-nbc-sitcoms-legacy |title='Not Very Entertaining, Clever, or Original": How NBC Almost Killed 'Friends' |date=September 12, 2014 |accessdate=September 17, 2015 |website=The New Republic |publisher=The New Republic |last=Harrison |first=Andrew |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150922044618/http://www.newrepublic.com/article/119434/friends-20th-anniversary-nbc-sitcoms-legacy |archivedate=September 22, 2015 |df= }} Because Monica and Joey were initially conceived as the show's two most sexual characters, Crane and Kauffman had originally intended for them to be the show's main couple, before ultimately replacing them with Ross and Rachel. The idea of Monica and Joey was abandoned once the role of Joey was cast; actor [[Matt LeBlanc]] approached his character using much more of a "big brother vibe" in terms of Joey's relationship with Cox's character as opposed to a romantic one, which the writers ultimately preferred. According to Allison Piwowarski of [[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]], Monica and Joey's relationship would have greatly altered the trajectory of the entire series, having life-changing effects on its characters.{{cite web|url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/61067-how-would-friends-have-been-different-if-monica-joey-were-the-main-couple-of-the |title=How Would 'Friends' Have Been Different If Monica & Joey Were The Main Couple Of The Series? |date=January 28, 2015 |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |website=Bustle |publisher= |last=Piwowarski |first=Allison |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150803093845/http://www.bustle.com/articles/61067-how-would-friends-have-been-different-if-monica-joey-were-the-main-couple-of-the |archivedate=August 3, 2015 |df= }} Summarizing the role of Monica in the series, Martin Gitlin wrote in his book ''The Greatest Sitcoms of All Time'' that while her friends "were ... just out to make the most of their social lives", Monica "sought to keep the others in line" while searching for "Mr. Right", who surprisingly turns out to be close friend Chandler.{{Cite book|title = The Greatest Sitcoms of All Time|last = Gillin|first = Martin|publisher = Scarecrow Press|year = 2013|isbn = 9780810887251|location = United States|pages = 165–166|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=QWQYAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA164&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false}} Several years before Monica and Chandler became romantically involved, Cox once joked in an interview that if her character were to ever have sex with another main character, it would most likely be Chandler.{{cite web|url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/60941-36-fun-facts-about-friends-that-every-fanatic-should-know |title=36 Fun Facts About 'Friends' That Every Fanatic Should Know |date=January 30, 2015 |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |website=Bustle |publisher= |last=Reilly |first=Kaitlin |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150806002357/http://www.bustle.com/articles/60941-36-fun-facts-about-friends-that-every-fanatic-should-know |archivedate=August 6, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/06/15/friends-show-trivia_n_7564546.html |title=11 More Things You Didn't Know About 'Friends,' Even If You're A Superfan |date=June 15, 2015 |accessdate=September 9, 2015 |website=The Huffington Post |publisher=TheHuffingtonPost.com, Inc |last=Luling |first=Todd Van |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150827095623/http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/06/15/friends-show-trivia_n_7564546.html |archivedate=August 27, 2015 |df= }} Crane and Kauffman had never intended to pair off Monica and Chandler with each other, and only decided to expand upon the idea of a relationship between the two friends upon realizing that viewers had "fallen in love" with the notion of Monica and Chandler as a couple.{{cite web|url=http://www.yourtango.com/2013199533/tv-love-22-things-you-didnt-know-about-friends |title=23 Awesome Things You Definitely Didn't Know About 'Friends' |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |website=YourTango |publisher=Tango Media Corporation |last=Kupfer |first=Lindsey |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150327112747/http://www.yourtango.com/2013199533/tv-love-22-things-you-didnt-know-about-friends |archivedate=March 27, 2015 |df= }} According to Robert Bianco of ''[[USA Today]]'', "Their affair came out of the blue and was supposed to quickly return there — but something in the relationship clicked with viewers."{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-04-14-revisiting-friends_x.htm |title=Not just another 'Friends' wedding |date=April 15, 2004 |access-date=January 20, 2016 |website=USA Today |publisher=Gannett Co. Inc. |last=Bianco |first=Robert |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160410110233/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-04-14-revisiting-friends_x.htm |archivedate=April 10, 2016 |df= }} The idea of Monica and Chandler's romantic arc originally surfaced much earlier in the series from writers [[Scott Silveri]] and [[Shana Goldberg-Meehan]], who first observed the characters' chemistry in the season two episode "[[The One Where Ross Finds Out]]", in which an idle and unemployed Monica is temporarily acting as Chandler's [[personal trainer]].{{cite web|url = http://www.vulture.com/2013/11/friends-monica-chandler-how-writers-paired-them-off.html|title = How Friends Decided to Pair Off Monica and Chandler|date = November 20, 2013|accessdate = September 7, 2015|website = Vulture|publisher = New York Media LLC|last = Adalian|first = Josef}} However, Silveri's suggestion was initially [[veto]]ed by the other writers, who felt that it was simply too soon to introduce another main couple to ''Friends'' having just recently paired off Ross and Rachel. Following Ross and Rachel's break up in season three, the writers felt that the timing was just about right to officially introduce Monica and Chandler as a couple, deciding that ''Friends'' "can't simply rest on this one [Ross and Rachel] relationship", while believing that Monica and Chandler's would ultimately provide a fun opportunity for the writers to explore brand new storylines. Silveri and Goldberg-Meehan deliberately intended to keep Monica and Chandler's union "low-key" in order to further differentiate it from Ross and Rachel's, which had been very public. In order to get an idea how audiences would react to Monica and Chandler hooking up at Ross and Emily's wedding in London, the scene in which a clearly nude Monica suddenly emerges from under the sheets of Chandler's [[Hotel bedding|hotel bed]] was filmed in front of three separate test audiences, each of whom responded very enthusiastically to the surprise, several months before the episode was actually taped. Despite the warm reception received from the audience, Silveri and Goldberg-Meehan were at first uncertain as to whether or not they should continue expanding upon their relationship even further, and proceeded with caution by having Monica and Chandler initially keep their relationship hidden from their peers. Protective of their characters, Cox and Perry shared similar hesitations at first, but ultimately grew to accept Monica and Chandler as a couple. The characters' relationship is eventually revealed to their friends in the episode "[[The One Where Everybody Finds Out]]".{{cite web|url = http://ca.ign.com/articles/2014/09/24/the-top-10-friends-episodes|title = The Top 10 Friends Episodes|date = September 24, 2014|accessdate = September 15, 2015|website = IGN|publisher = Ziff Davis LLC|last = |first = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150105061519/http://www.ign.com/articles/2014/09/24/the-top-10-friends-episodes|archivedate = January 5, 2015}} While each character very much approves of their union, Monica's parents initially resent their daughter's feelings for Chandler due to an age-old misunderstanding involving Chandler. Bianco observed that "On most shows, linking two main characters like Monica and Chandler would have been an act of desperation." However, "On ''Friends'', it was a stroke of genius that made both characters more appealing while providing a needed diversion from the show's central task: Retaining a romantic equilibrium between Ross and Rachel."{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-05-05-friends-appreciation_x.htm |title=So many reasons to salute this most affable of sitcoms |date=May 5, 2004 |access-date=January 17, 2016 |website=USA Today |publisher=USA TODAY |last=Bianco |first=Robert |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405055734/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-05-05-friends-appreciation_x.htm |archivedate=April 5, 2013 |df= }}{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-04-21-revisiting-friends_x.htm |title=Monica and Chandler's wedding kept the honeymoon going strong |date=April 21, 2004 |access-date=January 19, 2016 |website=USA Today |publisher=Gannett Co. Inc. |last=Bianco |first=Robert |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202190906/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-04-21-revisiting-friends_x.htm |archivedate=February 2, 2016 |df= }} Monica and Chandler's relationship is the antithesis of Ross and Rachel's because it remained "healthy and strong until the series ended", while the other couple was relentlessly [[On-again, off-again relationship|on-and-off]]. ''Encyclopedia of Television'' author Horace Newcomb believes that Monica's feelings for Chandler are responsible for curing the latter's [[fear of commitment]].{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Television |last=Newcomb |first=Horace |publisher=Routledge |year=2014 |isbn=9781135194727 |location=United Kingdom |page=935 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NUXIAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA935&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170402174133/https://books.google.com/books?id=NUXIAgAAQBAJ |archivedate=April 2, 2017 |df= }} Similarly, ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'' writer Ruth Graham observed that "Chandler is painted as a self-loathing loser with women, until he finally snags Monica at the end of Season 4."{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2015/01/22/friends_chandler_bing_and_his_homophobia_are_the_worst_thing_about_watching.html |title=Chandler Bing Is the Worst Thing About Watching Friends in 2015 |date=January 22, 2015 |accessdate=September 9, 2015 |website=Slate |publisher=The Slate Group LLC |last=Graham |first=Ruth |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150915174927/http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2015/01/22/friends_chandler_bing_and_his_homophobia_are_the_worst_thing_about_watching.html |archivedate=September 15, 2015 |df= }} Meanwhile, Silveri believes that ''Friends'' ultimately ran as long as it did due in part to Monica and Chandler's romance, explaining, "if the center of ''Friends'' had remained Ross and Rachel, you would've seen a much shorter shelf life for the show"; Monica and Chandler's arc is believed to have extended the series by approximately three years. Crane and Kauffman had always intended to give Monica and Chandler a child.{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2014/04/16/marta-kauffman-david-crane-friends-finale |title='Friends' creators Marta Kauffman and David Crane look back at the finale – and why they won't do a reunion show |date=April 16, 2014 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=Entertainment Weekly |publisher=Entertainment Weekly Inc |last=Snierson |first=Dan |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402113717/http://www.ew.com/article/2014/04/16/marta-kauffman-david-crane-friends-finale |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }} When it finally came time for them to write the finale, the idea of the couple adopting newborn twins was conceived at the last minute simply "for fun". The birth of Monica and Chandler's twins serves as one of the finale's main plots.{{Cite news|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=Jl9PAAAAIBAJ&sjid=LAQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3823,549338&hl=en|title = Going 'Friends'-less|last = Crook|first = John|date = May 2, 2004|work = The Toledo Blade|access-date = September 10, 2015|via = }} They were named Jack and Erica – after Monica's father and their birth mother, respectively. –{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2003-10-01-friends-recaps_x.htm |title=Catch up with 'Friends' episodes |date=January 16, 2004 |access-date=January 17, 2016 |website=USA Today |publisher=USA TODAY |last=Matheson |first=Whitney |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202190904/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2003-10-01-friends-recaps_x.htm |archivedate=February 2, 2016 |df= }} The twins are born three minutes and forty-six seconds apart.{{cite web|url=http://uproxx.com/tv/2014/05/10-thing-you-might-not-know-about-the-friends-finale-on-its-10th-anniversary/ |title=10 Things You Might Not Know About The ‘Friends’ Finale On Its 10th Anniversary |date=May 6, 2014 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=UPROXX |publisher= |last=Hawkins |first=Bennett |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160310204658/http://uproxx.com/tv/10-thing-you-might-not-know-about-the-friends-finale-on-its-10th-anniversary/ |archivedate=March 10, 2016 |df= }} Although the surprise addition of Monica and Chandler's twins was generally well received, critics questioned the fact that the babies are brought home from the hospital the same day as their delivery{{Cite web|url=http://cgi1.usatoday.com/mchat/20040507001/tscript.htm |title=The 'Friends' finale: USATODAY.com's Whitney Matheson |date=April 30, 2004 |access-date=January 17, 2016 |website=USA Today |publisher=USA TODAY |last=Matheson |first=Whitney |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130405053007/http://cgi1.usatoday.com/mchat/20040507001/tscript.htm |archivedate=April 5, 2013 |df= }} === Casting === Monica is portrayed by American actress [[Courteney Cox]].{{Cite news |url=http://courteneycox.org/articles/People240100.pdf |title=The Buddy System |last= |first= |date=January 24, 2000 |work=People |access-date=August 15, 2015 |via= |page=99 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150701110537/http://courteneycox.org/articles/People240100.pdf |archivedate=July 1, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} Crane and Kauffman had originally written the role of Monica for comedian [[Janeane Garofalo]],{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/courteney-cox-nicollette-sheridan-kelsey-grammer-ted-danson-nbc-top-of-the-rock-casting-308749 |title=Janeane Garofalo on 'Friends' Instead of Courteney Cox? Six Real Stories of Near-Miss Casting |date=April 6, 2012 |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |publisher= |last=Lewis |first=Andy |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005091638/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/courteney-cox-nicollette-sheridan-kelsey-grammer-ted-danson-nbc-top-of-the-rock-casting-308749 |archivedate=October 5, 2015 |df= }} their first choice,{{cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2011/01/23/role-play-2/ |title=Role play |date=January 23, 2011 |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |website=New York Post |publisher=Holdings, Inc |last=Rorke |first=Robert |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405202023/http://nypost.com/2011/01/23/role-play-2/ |archivedate=April 5, 2015 |df= }} because they were attracted to her "edgier and snarkier" voice. However, Garofalo ultimately turned down the offer.{{Cite book|title = The Indispensable Book of Useless Information: Just When You Thought It Couldn't Get Any More Useless—It Does|last = Voorhees|first = Don|publisher = Penguin|year = 2011|isbn = 9781101514795|location = United Kingdom|pages = |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=A479XLrmk54C&pg=PT30&lpg=PT30&dq=janeane+garofalo+first+choice+friends#v=onepage&q=janeane%20garofalo%20first%20choice%20friends&f=false}} Actress [[Jami Gertz]] was also offered the role but declined,{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnewyork.com/entertainment/movies/Cast-Aside-Actors-Who-Almost-Got-the-Part-82445617.html |title=Cast Aside: Actors Who Almost Had the Part |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |website=NBC New York |publisher=NBCUniversal Media, LLC |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150801030310/http://www.nbcnewyork.com/entertainment/movies/Cast-Aside-Actors-Who-Almost-Got-the-Part-82445617.html |archivedate=August 1, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.0code.net/the-alternate-reality-friends-cast-will-blow-your-tv-loving-mind/ |title=The Alternate Reality Friends Cast Will Blow Your TV-Loving Mind |date=April 5, 2012 |accessdate=October 17, 2015 |website=Ocode.net |publisher=0code.net |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151117031559/http://www.0code.net/the-alternate-reality-friends-cast-will-blow-your-tv-loving-mind/ |archivedate=November 17, 2015 |df= }} while actress [[Leah Remini]] auditioned for Monica before ultimately being cast as [[Carrie Heffernan]] in the sitcom ''[[The King of Queens]]'' in 1998;{{cite web|url=http://uproxx.com/tv/2012/04/the-cast-of-friends-that-couldve-been/ |title=The Cast of 'Friends' That Could've Been |date=April 4, 2012 |accessdate=April 13, 2015 |website=UPROXX |publisher= |last=Rowles |first=Dustin |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150508080000/http://uproxx.com/tv/2012/04/the-cast-of-friends-that-couldve-been/ |archivedate=May 8, 2015 |df= }} Remini would eventually [[guest star]] in an episode of ''Friends''.{{cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2011/03/the-lost-roles-of-friends/ |title=The Lost Roles of Friends |date=March 10, 2011 |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |website=Splitsider |publisher= |last=Evans |first=Bradford |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402134912/http://splitsider.com/2011/03/the-lost-roles-of-friends/ |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }} Before being cast as Monica in ''Friends'', Cox was best known for appearing in singer [[Bruce Springsteen]]'s "[[Dancing in the Dark (Bruce Springsteen song)|Dancing in the Dark]]" music video; within the television industry for her [[recurring role]] as Lauren Miller, [[Alex P. Keaton]]'s girlfriend, on the sitcom ''[[Family Ties]]''; and Melissa Robinson in the comedy film ''[[Ace Ventura: Pet Detective]]'' (1994), opposite [[Jim Carrey]]. After guest starring on the sitcom ''[[Seinfeld]]'' as Meryl,{{Cite book|title = Seinfeld Reference: The Complete Encyclopedia with Biographies, Character Profiles & Episode Summaries|last = Bjorklund|first = Dennis|publisher = Praetorian Publishing|year = 2013|isbn = 9781492391241|location = United States|pages = |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=9RyY2Mtqk54C&pg=PT212&dq=monica+geller+courteney+cox#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20courteney%20cox&f=false}} main character [[Jerry Seinfeld (character)|Jerry Seinfeld]]'s girlfriend,{{cite web|url = http://www.people.com/people/courteney_cox/biography|title = Courteney Cox – Biography|accessdate = August 12, 2015|website = People|publisher = Time Inc|last = Wang|first = Julia|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150905092204/http://www.people.com/people/courteney_cox/biography|archivedate = September 5, 2015}} the producers offered Cox the role of Monica's spoiled best friend Rachel because the actress "had this cheery, upbeat energy", which was significantly different than how they had envisioned Monica at the time. Feeling she was not "quirky" enough to portray Rachel,{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/tv/news/friends-six-lives-on-videotape-19950518?page=3 |title='Friends': Six Lives on Videotape |date=May 18, 1995 |accessdate=September 17, 2015 |website=Rolling Stone |publisher=Rolling Stone |last=Wild |first=David |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150414080311/http://www.rollingstone.com/tv/news/friends-six-lives-on-videotape-19950518?page=3 |archivedate=April 14, 2015 |df= }} Cox lobbied in favor of playing Monica instead because she was drawn to the character's "strong" personality,{{cite web|url = http://mentalfloss.com/article/56565/25-things-you-might-not-know-about-friends|title = 25 Things You Might Not Know About Friends|date = September 22, 2014|accessdate = August 12, 2015|website = Mental Floss|publisher = Mental Floss, Inc|last = Danko|first = Meredith}} but the producers feared that she was not "tough" enough for the role,{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CjIQmp2llUQC&pg=PA163&lpg=PA163&dq=muddling+through+jennifer+aniston+friends#v=onepage&q=muddling%20through%20jennifer%20aniston%20friends&f=false|title=Jennifer Aniston: The Unauthorized Biography|last=Smith|first=Sean|publisher=Pan Macmillan|year=2008|isbn=9780283063893|location=United Kingdom|pages=151–161|quote=|via=Google Books}} which was offered to actress [[Jennifer Aniston]], alongside whom Cox would eventually co-star. Meanwhile, a close competitor for the role was actress [[Nancy McKeon]];{{cite web|url=http://parade.com/256060/ashleighschmitz/which-facts-of-life-star-auditioned-to-be-rachel-on-friends/ |title=Which Facts of Life Star Could Have Been Rachel on Friends? |date=January 23, 2014 |accessdate=September 8, 2015 |website=Parade |publisher=Athlon Media Group |last=Schmitz |first=Ashleigh |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005101249/http://parade.com/256060/ashleighschmitz/which-facts-of-life-star-auditioned-to-be-rachel-on-friends/ |archivedate=October 5, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|url = http://ca.eonline.com/photos/10473/amazing-tv-roles-that-almost-went-to-other-actors/349291|title = Amazing TV Roles That Almost Went to Other Actors|date = |accessdate = September 8, 2015|website = E!|publisher = Entertainment Television, LLC|last = |first = }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Littlefield recalled having greatly enjoyed both actress' auditions equally, and left the final decision up to Crane and Kauffman. Ultimately, Cox won the role over McKeon because the creators noticed "something fresh" in her audition; Kauffman elaborated that Cox ultimately "brought a whole bunch of other colors" to Monica than what they had first envisioned back when they were considering Garofalo for the part. Meanwhile, Aniston ultimately won the role of Rachel. [[File:CourteneyCoxFeb09.jpg|thumb|The show's most famous main cast member at the time, actress Courteney Cox was originally offered the role of Rachel; she ultimately turned it down because she was attracted to Monica's "strong" personality.]] Each main cast member auditioned for ''Friends'' having had some degree of prior sitcom experience.{{Cite book|title = Sitcom: A History in 24 Episodes from I Love Lucy to Community|last = Austerlitz|first = Saul|publisher = Chicago Review Press|year = 2014|isbn = 9781613743874|location = United States|page = 261|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=ydDFAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA261&dq=monica+geller+courteney+cox#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20courteney%20cox&f=false}} Before finally being cast in ''Friends'', Cox's burgeoning success as an actress had heavily relied on her physical appearance.{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1995-06-18/entertainment/ca-14208_1_courteney-cox |title=TELEVISION : Miss Almost Perfect : Courteney Cox is beautiful and funny, which helps because she stars in the hit comedy series 'Friends.' So we can forgive that she's a neatness freak too. |date=June 18, 1995 |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |website=Los Angeles Times |publisher=Los Angeles Times |last=Weinstein |first=Steve |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005045243/http://articles.latimes.com/1995-06-18/entertainment/ca-14208_1_courteney-cox |archivedate=October 5, 2015 |df= }} Unlike her previous roles in projects such as ''Family Ties'' and ''Ace Ventura: Pet Detective'', the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' Steve Weinstein believes that Monica was the first major role in which Cox was cast based on her abilities as a comedic actress as opposed to her beauty. Cox believes that she owes winning the role to her brief stint as Gabriella Easden on the short-lived sitcom ''[[The Trouble with Larry]]'', which she considers to be the first time she played a character who "was the funny one", which in turn earned the actress a recommendation for ''Friends'' following its cancellation. When ''Friends'' premiered, Cox was the show's most famous main cast member among a cast of young, relatively unknown actors, and was thus initially perceived by critics and audiences as the show's star, despite Crane and Kauffman's efforts to promote ''Friends'' as an [[Ensemble cast|ensemble comedy]]. According to actress [[Lisa Kudrow]], who portrays Phoebe, Cox is responsible for suggesting that the entire cast work together as a team.{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2012/04/friends-oral-history-jennifer-aniston-rachel-green |title=The Oral History of Friends: Jennifer Aniston Almost Didn’t Play Rachel Green |date=April 4, 2012 |accessdate=August 13, 2015 |website=Vanity Fair |publisher=Condé Nast |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150822170631/http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2012/04/friends-oral-history-jennifer-aniston-rachel-green |archivedate=August 22, 2015 |df= }} As the most experienced cast member at the time, Cox advised her co-stars to remain open to each other's ideas, notes and suggestions, while giving them permission to tell her "If I could do anything funnier". Cox was originally the highest-paid cast member.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/shameless-emmy-rossum-resolves-salary-standoff-paving-way-season-8-956129 |title='Shameless': Emmy Rossum Resolves Salary Standoff, Paving Way for Season 8 |last=Goldberg |first=Lesley |date=December 14, 2016 |work=The Hollywood Reporter |publisher= |access-date=December 15, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161215124355/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/shameless-emmy-rossum-resolves-salary-standoff-paving-way-season-8-956129 |archivedate=December 15, 2016 |df= }} Preferring to be treated as equals, the entire cast negotiated for universal salaries, demanding that Warner Bros. accommodate their request of $100,000 per episode in season three, increased from their original inaugural season salary of $22,000 per episode. At one point, the actors went as far as threatening to boycott their own show should their demands be denied,{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/16/arts/friends-cast-bands-together-to-demand-a-salary-increase.html |title=Friends' Cast Bands Together To Demand a Salary Increase |date=July 16, 1996 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |last=Carter |first=Bill |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403040339/http://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/16/arts/friends-cast-bands-together-to-demand-a-salary-increase.html |archivedate=April 3, 2015 |df= }} temporarily refusing to renew their expired contracts.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2000/04/21/friends-demand-raise |title=''Friends'' demand a raise |date=April 21, 2000 |access-date=January 17, 2016 |website=Entertainment Weekly |publisher=Entertainment Weekly In |last=Rice |first=Lynette |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160116183150/http://www.ew.com/article/2000/04/21/friends-demand-raise |archivedate=January 16, 2016 |df= }} The studio eventually complied, and by season 10 each actor was being paid $1 million per episode,{{cite web|url = http://www.bustle.com/articles/60941-36-fun-facts-about-friends-that-every-fanatic-should-know|title = 36 Fun Facts About 'Friends' That Every Fanatic Should Know|date = January 30, 2015|accessdate = August 13, 2015|website = Bustle|publisher = |last = Reilly|first = Kaitlin}} making Cox and her female co-stars the highest-paid television actresses of all time.{{cite web|url = http://ca.ign.com/stars/jennifer-aniston|title = Jennifer Aniston – About This Person|date = |accessdate = October 6, 2015|website = IGN|publisher = Ziff Davis, LLC|last = |first = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150714170430/http://www.ign.com/stars/jennifer-aniston|archivedate = July 14, 2015}} Cox was 30 years old at the time she was cast, making her the show's second oldest main cast member, and was 39 by the beginning of ''Friends''{{'}} final season.{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-05-05-friends-farewell-main_x.htm |title=And now, the one where 'Friends' says goodbye |date=May 5, 2015 |access-date=January 17, 2016 |website=USA Today |publisher=USA TODAY |last=Oldenburg |first=Ann |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160706044254/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-05-05-friends-farewell-main_x.htm |archivedate=July 6, 2016 |df= }} Additionally, this distinction makes Cox older than her on-screen brother, actor [[David Schwimmer]], who portrays her older brother Ross,{{cite web|url = https://www.buzzfeed.com/tabathaleggett/things-you-probably-didnt-know-about-friends#.yoyEqAK7n|title = 61 Things You Probably Didn’t Know About "Friends"|date = July 22, 2014|accessdate = August 12, 2015|website = BuzzFeed|publisher = BuzzFeed Inc|last = Leggett|first = Tabatha|last2 = Edds|first2 = Robin}} who is one year her senior.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ibnlive.com/news/lifestyle-2/6-lessons-we-need-to-learn-from-ross-and-monica-geller-this-raksha-bandhan-1055241.html |title=6 lessons we need to learn from Ross and Monica Geller this Raksha Bandhan |date=August 29, 2015 |accessdate=January 1, 2015 |website=IBNLive |publisher=IBNLive.com |last=Tulsiani |first=Kriti |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304193824/http://www.ibnlive.com/news/lifestyle-2/6-lessons-we-need-to-learn-from-ross-and-monica-geller-this-raksha-bandhan-1055241.html |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df= }} The actress would deliver Monica's lines emphatically.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/81257-7-ways-were-all-monica-geller-from-friends-because-she-was-totally-the-most-relatable |title=7 Ways We're All Monica Geller From 'Friends,' Because She Was Totally The Most Relatable |date=May 15, 2015 |accessdate=January 3, 2015 |website=Bustle |publisher= |last=Tison |first=James |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160205104037/http://www.bustle.com/articles/81257-7-ways-were-all-monica-geller-from-friends-because-she-was-totally-the-most-relatable |archivedate=February 5, 2016 |df= }} Although each character is depicted as an avid coffee drinker, spending much of their free time in a coffee house, Cox herself does not drink coffee, and was only pretending to drink it out of mugs on the show.{{Cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/2003-10-08-cox_x.htm |title=A revealing sit-down with Courteney Cox |date=October 9, 2013 |access-date=January 20, 2016 |website=USA Today |publisher=Gannett Co. Inc. |last=Oldenburg |first=Ann |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160202190858/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/2003-10-08-cox_x.htm |archivedate=February 2, 2016 |df= }} Kauffman believes that Cox's own cleanliness closely resembles her character's; at times the actress would clean her co-stars' [[Changing room|dressing rooms]]. Cox also shares the character's motherly nature.{{Cite news |url=http://courteneycox.org/articles/US0296.pdf |title=GIRL Friends |last=Rhodes |first=Joe |work=Us Weekly |access-date=August 13, 2015 |via= |pages=38–42 |date=February 1996 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150701110615/http://courteneycox.org/articles/US0296.pdf |archivedate=July 1, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} The actress enjoyed portraying Monica she was able to "bring more of my own personality to her, and I've never really been able to do that before." Starpulse.com observed that "As Monica, Cox never quite enjoyed the sort of watercooler storylines that co-star ... Jennifer Aniston had with David Schwimmer as the on-again, off-again Rachel and Ross."{{cite web|url=http://www.starpulse.com/Actresses/Cox,_Courteney/Biography/ |title=Courteney Cox Biography |date= |accessdate=August 25, 2015 |website=Starpulse.com |publisher=Starpulse.com |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150918231640/http://www.starpulse.com/Actresses/Cox%2C_Courteney/Biography/ |archivedate=September 18, 2015 |df= }} At one point, Cox had begun to regret her decision to accept the role of Monica over Rachel due to the character's lack of strong storylines; she eventually relented once Monica and Chandler became romantically involved, thus her character's storylines gradually began to improve. Cox married actor [[David Arquette]] in 1999 while the show was on hiatus between seasons five and six, hence the actress legally changed her full name to Courteney Cox Arquette.{{cite web|url = http://metro.co.uk/2014/09/22/19-friends-facts-you-actually-didnt-know-4872196/|title = As Friends celebrates its 20th anniversary: 19 Friends facts you ACTUALLY really didn’t know|date = September 22, 2014|accessdate = August 13, 2015|website = Metro|publisher = Associated Newspapers Limited|last = Stewart|first = Ellen}} The opening credits of the season six premiere "[[The One After Vegas]]" features an [[in-joke|inside joke]] in which Cox's new surname "Arquette" is attached to the surnames of each cast and crew member. The episode is dedicated to Cox and Arquette, reading, "For Courteney and David, who did get married." Before marrying Cox, Arquette had guest starred in an episode of ''Friends'' as Phoebe's love interest. During season 10, Cox got pregnant with her and Arquette's child.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,627509,00.html |title=A New Friend: Courteney Cox Pregnant |date=January 6, 2004 |accessdate=September 11, 2015 |website=People |publisher=Time Inc |last=Silverman |first=Stephen M |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150914195919/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C627509%2C00.html |archivedate=September 14, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} At that same time, her character and on-screen husband were going through the process of adopting a child. Like Monica and Chandler, Cox and Arquette had also struggled with conceiving in real life. Although Kudrow's real-life pregnancy had successfully been written into the show,{{cite web|url = http://www.yourtango.com/2013199533/tv-love-22-things-you-didnt-know-about-friends|title = 23 Awesome Things You Definitely Didn't Know About 'Friends'|accessdate = August 13, 2015|website = YourTango|publisher = Tango Media Corporation|last = Kupfer|first = Lindsey}} the same could not have been done for Cox because ''Friends'' had already long-established that Monica is incapable of having children.{{cite web|url = http://popcrush.com/pregnant-celebrities-while-filming/|title = 19 Celebrities Who Were Pregnant While FIlming|date = June 27, 2014|accessdate = September 11, 2015|website = PopCrush|publisher = POPCRUSH NETWORK|last = Malach|first = Maggie|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150921184415/http://popcrush.com/pregnant-celebrities-while-filming/|archivedate = September 21, 2015}} Therefore, the crew attempted to conceal Cox's pregnancy using a combination of baggy, loose-fitting costumes and props instead. However, at times the actress' growing belly was still detectable by viewers in spite of the crew's best efforts.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20754918,00.html |title=How TV Shows Have Hidden Stars's Pregnancies |date=November 14, 2013 |accessdate=September 11, 2015 |website=People |publisher=Time Inc |last=Hefa |first=Kiran |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909234905/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C20754918%2C00.html |archivedate=September 9, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} == Characterization and themes == === Codependency and neuroticism === At the beginning of season one, Monica is 25 years old.{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2001/09/15/friends-5 |title=Friends |date=September 15, 2001 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=Entertainment Weekly |publisher=Entertainment Weekly Inc |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151007225427/http://www.ew.com/article/2001/09/15/friends-5 |archivedate=October 7, 2015 |df= }} Rita Loiacono of [[SheKnows Media]] believes that Monica is the show's most fully realized character from the very beginning of the series because her "quirks were developed to a tee." Like several [[Strong female character|strong female sitcom characters]] who were popular throughout the 1980s and 1990s, Monica possesses a natural maternal instinct, constantly "vocalising a desire for motherhood."{{Cite book|title = From Happy Homemaker to Desperate Housewives: Motherhood and Popular Television|last = Feasey|first = Rebecca|publisher = Anthem Press|year = 2012|isbn = 9780857285614|location = United States|page = 39|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=nIlJ7EJr1RcC&pg=PA39&dq=monica+geller+courteney+cox#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20courteney%20cox&f=false}} As the group's "unofficial den mother,"{{cite web|url = http://www.sitcomsonline.com/photopost/showphoto.php/photo/21903/si/Terror|title = Friends|date = July 5, 2004|accessdate = August 11, 2015|website = Sitcoms Online|publisher = All Enthusiast, Inc|last = |first = }} Monica occupies the role of their [[Codependency|mother hen]],{{cite web|url=http://gentwenty.com/the-5-roommates-we-all-have-to-have/ |title=The 5 roommates we all have to have |date=November 26, 2013 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=GenTwenty |publisher=GenTwenty |last=Phillips |first=Shelley |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304055846/http://gentwenty.com/the-5-roommates-we-all-have-to-have/ |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df= }} and is thus often perceived as the most level-headed member of the sextet, with Ken Parish Perkins of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' identifying Monica as the show's most grounded character.{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-09-21/features/9409210125_1_seinfeld-friends-poignant-show |title=A Singular Formula |date=September 21, 1994 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=Chicago Tribune |publisher= |last=Perkins |first=Ken Parish |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926010315/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1994-09-21/features/9409210125_1_seinfeld-friends-poignant-show |archivedate=September 26, 2015 |df= }} Jill O'Rourke of Crushable described her as "the glue that held the group together."{{cite web|url=http://www.crushable.com/2013/03/20/entertainment/christy-carlson-romano-ren-stevens-type-a-characters/ |title=An Ode To Ren Stevens And Other Type A Girls On TV |date=2013 |accessdate=September 18, 2015 |website=Crushable |publisher=Defy Media, LLC |last=O'Rourke |first=Jill |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005035403/http://www.crushable.com/2013/03/20/entertainment/christy-carlson-romano-ren-stevens-type-a-characters/ |archivedate=October 5, 2015 |df= }} [[Ken Tucker]] of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' believes that Monica serves as "the solid center in a circle of wacky pals" due to her "sunny" personality, combined with the fact that she maintains a secure job while appearing to possess the most [[common sense]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/article/1994/10/21/tv-show-review-winning-friends |title=TV Show Review: Winning 'Friends' |date=October 21, 1994 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=Entertainment Weekly |publisher=Entertainment Weekly Inc |last=Tucker |first=Ken |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402105439/http://www.ew.com/article/1994/10/21/tv-show-review-winning-friends |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }} Furthermore, Tucker identified Monica as the show's "[[Straight man|straight woman]]." Writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[John J. O'Connor (journalist)|John J. O'Connor]] believes that Monica exhibits "the strongest ties to reality" as the sitcom's most realistically portrayed character.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/29/arts/television-review-yes-more-friends-sitting-around.html |title=TELEVISION REVIEW; Yes, More Friends Sitting Around |date=September 29, 1994 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |last=O'Connor |first=John J |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929015758/http://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/29/arts/television-review-yes-more-friends-sitting-around.html |archivedate=September 29, 2015 |df= }} [[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]]'s James Tison agreed that Monica is the show's most relatable character. Referring to Monica as one-half of the series' "head friends," the ''[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|Pittsburgh Post-Gazette's]]'' Robert Bianco described the character as sensible, explaining that both her and brother Ross represent "the relatively stable centers around which the other friends rotate."{{cite web|url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=IYwNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ym8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3371,4064656&hl=en|title = Six 'Friends' sittin' around, talking|date = September 22, 1994|accessdate = August 11, 2015|website = Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|publisher = PG Publishing Co., Inc|last = Bianco|first = Robert}} Describing her as "ultra-competent," ''Natural Living Today''{{'}}s Emily Nussbaum likened Monica to the fairy tale character [[Snow White]], on whose [[homemaking]] skills the five other main characters heavily rely, similar to the relationship between Snow White and the seven dwarfs.{{Cite news |url=http://courteneycox.org/articles/NLT.pdf |title=Best Friend |last=Nussbaum |first=Emily |work=Natural Living Today |access-date=August 14, 2015 |date=March 1998 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150714033347/http://courteneycox.org/articles/NLT.pdf |archivedate=July 14, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} Although Monica began ''Friends'' as the show's straight person, the writers eventually made her funnier by incorporating aspects of Cox's own personality into the character, in addition to writing wittier material for her.{{Cite book|title = Cosmopolitan, Volume 218|last = |first = |publisher = Hearst Corporation|year = 1995|isbn = |location = |page = 240|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=F2lNAQAAIAAJ&q=monica+geller+courteney+cox&dq=monica+geller+courteney+cox}} [[File:OCD handwash.jpg|thumb|Monica's personality contains several traits commonly associated with [[Obsessive–compulsive disorder|obsessive-compulsive]] disorder, but are never explicitly classified as such.|left]] Identified by Ayn Bernos of ''[[Thought Catalog]]'' as "the epitome of a ... [[control freak]]",{{Cite web|url=http://thoughtcatalog.com/ayn-bernos/2014/09/5-signs-youre-a-real-life-monica-geller/ |title=5 Signs You’re A Real-Life Monica Geller |date=September 3, 2014 |accessdate=January 2, 2015 |website=Thought Catalog |publisher=The Thought & Expression Co |last=Bernos |first=Ayn |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150103005625/http://thoughtcatalog.com/ayn-bernos/2014/09/5-signs-youre-a-real-life-monica-geller/ |archivedate=January 3, 2015 |df= }} [[Refinery29|Refinery29's]] Kelsey Miller summarized Monica's personality as funny, uptight, loving, and competitive.{{cite web|url=http://www.refinery29.com/fat-characters-tv-movies#page-1 |title=The Problem With Fat Monica |date=December 22, 2015 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=Refinery29 |publisher=Refinery29 |last=Miller |first=Kelsey |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005065222/http://www.refinery29.com/fat-characters-tv-movies |archivedate=October 5, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} A very organized character with a signature [[Type A and Type B personality theory|Type A personality]] who enjoys being in charge,{{cite web|url=http://www.thegrindstone.com/2011/08/05/office-politics/management-lessons-from-tv-what-we-can-learn-from-friendss-monica-gellar-bing/ |title=Management Lessons From TV: What We Can Learn From ‘Friends’s’ Monica Geller Bing |date=2011 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=TheGrindstone |publisher=Defy Media, LLC |last=Lepore |first=Meredith |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304054644/http://www.thegrindstone.com/2011/08/05/office-politics/management-lessons-from-tv-what-we-can-learn-from-friendss-monica-gellar-bing/ |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df= }} Monica is known for being a "neat freak" obsessed with cleanliness –{{Cite book|title = From Abba to Zoom: A Pop Culture Encyclopedia of the Late 20th Century|last = Mansour|first = David|publisher = Andrews McMeel Publishing|year = 2011|isbn = 9780740793073|location = United States|page = 170|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=7GN0E_diWbAC&pg=PA170&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false}} especially when it comes to maintaining the impeccable condition of her apartment –{{cite web|url=http://www.buddytv.com/info/courteney-cox-info.aspx |title=Courteney Cox |date= |accessdate=August 25, 2015 |website=BuddyTV |publisher=BuddyTV |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001221841/http://www.buddytv.com/info/courteney-cox-info.aspx |archivedate=October 1, 2015 |df= }} neurotic,{{Cite book|title = 21st Century Political Science: A Reference Handbook|last = Ishiyama|first = John T|publisher = SAGE Publications|year = 2010|isbn = 9781483305462|location = United States|page = 358|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=_Er7CAAAQBAJ&pg=PA358&dq=monica+geller+courteney+cox#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20courteney%20cox&f=false}} extremely obsessive-compulsive, and competitive in nature,{{cite web|url=http://www.soundboard.com/sb/monica_friends_sounds |title=Monica from Friends |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=Soundboard |publisher=soundboard |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924103952/http://www.soundboard.com/sb/monica_friends_sounds |archivedate=September 24, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jun/09/news/la-en-courteneycox-20100609 |title=Courteney Cox: Shining through |date=June 9, 2010 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=Los Angeles Times |publisher=Los Angeles Times |last=Whipp |first=Glenn |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005050747/http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jun/09/news/la-en-courteneycox-20100609 |archivedate=October 5, 2015 |df= }}{{Cite book|title = Writing With Emotion, Tension, and Conflict: Techniques for Crafting an Expressive and Compelling Novel|last = St. John|first = Cheryl|publisher = Writer's Digest Books|year = 2013|isbn = 9781599637648|location = United States|page = 209|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=mZa7AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA209&lpg=PA209&dq=monica+geller+mother+hen#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20mother%20hen&f=false}} personality traits that are exaggerated for humor and [[comic relief]];{{Cite web|url=http://www.gusreview.com/monica-gellers-invisible-struggle-with-ocd/ |title=Monica Geller’s In/Visible OCD |date= |accessdate=January 2, 2015 |website=gusreview |publisher=Pierson A. Harleth Press |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304074516/http://www.gusreview.com/monica-gellers-invisible-struggle-with-ocd/ |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df= }} the writers did not begin to take full comedic advantage of Monica's neuroses until the show's first Thanksgiving episode. The character is also the loudest of her friends. In her book ''Writing With Emotion, Tension, and Conflict: Techniques for Crafting an Expressive and Compelling Novel'', author Cheryl St. John wrote that Monica exhibits qualities commonly associated with [[Perfectionism (psychology)|perfectionism]] and bossiness. James Tison of [[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]] wrote that Monica's cleanliness and bossiness often relinquishes her to being "the lame one" among her friends, although "she proved that sometimes rules and responsibility were important". However, the ''Los Angeles Times'''s Steve Weinstein observed that Monica's actions often tend to contradict her "Miss Perfect" image and reputation, explaining that the character frequently "makes a fool of herself" in addition to being "so compulsively neat that just her facial expressions of discomfort at one of her friends' messing things up in her apartment is enough to provoke genuine chuckles." Although several of Monica's personality traits and mannerisms make the character a strong candidate for [[Obsessive–compulsive disorder|obsessive-compulsive disorder]], they are treated as "quirky and amusing" as opposed to a disability or disease; her friends either ignore or find humor in her peculiarities. As creator and writer, Kauffman confirmed that Monica's extremely organized personality is based on her own, explaining, "I have a lot of Monica in me, in terms of everything having to be a certain way." Writing about the development of Monica's personality in ''[[USA Today]]'', Robert Bianco observed that the character gradually evolves from "the caring, nurturing mother figure ... into a slightly off-the-beam benevolent monarch."{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-03-03-revisiting-friends_x.htm |title='Friends' played great game of poker |date=March 3, 2004 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=USA Today |publisher=USA TODAY |last=Bianco |first=Robert |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150810002915/http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-03-03-revisiting-friends_x.htm |archivedate=August 10, 2015 |df= }} By the show's final season, Monica's personality has been "exacerbated for comedy" to the point of which she becomes borderline "cartoonish."{{cite web|url=http://www.diamondbackonline.com/diversions/arts/the-lasting-impact-of-your-favorite-friends/article_fc051790-4440-11e4-9d0b-001a4bcf6878.html |title=The lasting impact of your favorite 'Friends' |date=September 25, 2014 |accessdate=September 18, 2015 |website=The Diamondback |publisher=The Diamondback |last=Levy |first=Dustin |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160219213403/http://www.diamondbackonline.com/diversions/arts/the-lasting-impact-of-your-favorite-friends/article_fc051790-4440-11e4-9d0b-001a4bcf6878.html |archivedate=February 19, 2016 |df= }} === Family and childhood; career and love life === Monica has a complicated relationship with her parents [[Jack Geller|Jack]] ([[Elliott Gould|Elliot Gould]]) and [[Judy Geller]] ([[Christina Pickles]]), more-so with her mother.{{Cite book|title = Television Dialogue: The Sitcom Friends Vs. Natural Conversation|last = John Benjamins Publishing|first = Quaglio|publisher = Paulo|year = 2009|isbn = 9789027223104|location = Amsterdam|page = 19|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=TBq8ezZQopAC&pg=PT32&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false}} ''Entertainment Weekly'' referred to the character's relationship with her parents as "esteem-sucking." In fact, the majority of ''Friends'' main characters have "strained relationships" with their parents.{{Cite book|title = Millennial Makeover: MySpace, YouTube, and the Future of US-American Politics|last = Winograd|first = Morley|publisher = Rutgers University Press|year = 2008|isbn = 9780813544663|location = United States|page = 76|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=es5Fo0LNk24C&pg=PA76&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false|last2 = Hais|first2 = Michael D}} Described as "hypercritical,"{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/features/in-pictures-from-the-mother-of-all-on-screen-monsters-to-the-soap-mums-youd-like-to-adopt-8527006.html |title=In pictures: From the mother of all on-screen monsters to the soap mums you'd like to adopt |date=March 8, 2015 |accessdate=September 20, 2015 |website=The Independent |publisher= |last=Wyatt |first=Daisy |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003031822/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/features/in-pictures-from-the-mother-of-all-on-screen-monsters-to-the-soap-mums-youd-like-to-adopt-8527006.html |archivedate=October 3, 2015 |df= }} Judy enjoys constantly criticizing her daughter's appearance, career, and love life,{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/friends-gallery-1.90286?pmSlide=1.90915 |title='Friends': Where are they now? – Christina Pickles and Elliot Gould (Judy and Jack Geller) |date= |accessdate=September 9, 2015 |website=Daily News |publisher= |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151002105714/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/friends-gallery-1.90286?pmSlide=1.90915 |archivedate=October 2, 2015 |df= }} while acting much kinder towards her son, whom she favors. Chelsea Mize of [[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]] wrote that Monica and Ross' "wacky quirks become all the more understandable after ... seeing them with their parents."{{cite web|url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/90363-9-friends-geller-family-moments-thatll-prove-that-jack-judy-were-the-real-friends-stars |title=9 ‘Friends’ Geller Family Moments That’ll Prove That Jack & Judy Were The Real ‘Friends’ Stars |date=June 29, 2015 |accessdate=September 20, 2015 |website=Bustle |publisher= |last=Mize |first=Chelsea |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151003205952/http://www.bustle.com/articles/90363-9-friends-geller-family-moments-thatll-prove-that-jack-judy-were-the-real-friends-stars |archivedate=October 3, 2015 |df= }} ''Encyclopedia of Television Shows, 1925 through 2010'' author Vincent Terrance believes that Monica's competitiveness originates from having grown up with Ross as a brother, against whom she often competed as a child.{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Television Shows, 1925 through 2010, 2d ed |last=Terrance |first=Vincent |publisher=McFarland |year=2008 |isbn=9780786486410 |location=United States |page=368 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YX_daEhlnbsC&pg=PA368&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160629175135/https://books.google.com/books?id=YX_daEhlnbsC |archivedate=June 29, 2016 |df= }} Kriti Tulsiani of [[IBNLive]] described Monica and Ross' relationship as "A blend of love and sibling jealousy with an urge to irritate each other to the deepest core of existence", with Ross often making fun of his sister's weight and Monica teasing him about his several failed marriages in return. In terms of ethnicity, Crane confirmed that both Monica and Ross are half-[[Jews|Jewish]], with their father being Jewish and their mother being of non-Jewish European ancestry.{{Cite book|title = Television's Changing Image of American Jews|last = |first = |publisher = The Norman Lear Center|year = 2000|isbn = 9780971401860|location = United States|page = 46|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Qt_kzdotGWAC&pg=PA46&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false}} However, ''Television's Changing Image of American Jews'' categorized Monica as a "masked" Jew, explaining that "the smart, funny, and insecure Ross seems more Jewish" than Monica, who the author dismissed as "[[china doll|china-doll]] like" in appearance and demeanor. In his book ''Encyclopedia of American Jewish History, Volume 1'', author Stephen Harlan Norwood agrees that, unlike the show's male Jews, Monica's Jewish "markers" have been virtually removed.{{Cite book|title=Encyclopedia of American Jewish History, Volume 1 |last=Harlan Norwood |first=Stephen |publisher=ABC-CLIO |year=2008 |isbn=9781851096381 |location=United States |page=479 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IB3mBsgfIHQC&pg=PA479&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false |volume=1 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140608115849/http://books.google.com/books?id=IB3mBsgfIHQC |archivedate=June 8, 2014 |df= }} [[File:Christina Pickles.jpg|thumb|271x271px|Actress [[Christina Pickles]] portrays Monica's hypercritical mother, [[List of Friends characters|Judy Geller]].]] Although Monica and Rachel have remained best friends since high school, they are very much opposites.{{cite web|url=http://thiswastv.com/2013/05/01/women-in-the-box-rachel-green-monica-geller-and-phoebe-buffay-friends/ |title=Women in the Box: Rachel Green, Monica Geller, and Phoebe Buffay, Friends |date=May 1, 2013 |accessdate=August 26, 2015 |website=This Was Television |publisher= |last=Bowman |first=Sabienna |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150913022231/http://thiswastv.com/2013/05/01/women-in-the-box-rachel-green-monica-geller-and-phoebe-buffay-friends/ |archivedate=September 13, 2015 |df= }} While both characters share similar economic backgrounds, they grew up on "different ends of the high school social order," with Rachel being a popular cheerleader and Monica "deal[ing] with body and control issues due to being an overweight child and teen." Sabienna Bowman of This Was TV observed that "Monica’s struggles ultimately left her more confident than Rachel, as well as more prepared for adulthood." Among her defining qualities, Monica has had a passion for cooking ever since childhood, stemming from when she received her first [[Easy-Bake Oven]]. A chef, the character has had several cooking-related jobs throughout the series, having worked at five different restaurants,{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/oct/16/the-10-best-fictional-chefs-bradley-cooper-burnt-tv-film-screen-artie-bucco-ratatouille-soup-nazi |title=The 10 best fictional chefs |date=October 16, 2015 |access-date=January 18, 2016 |website=The Guardian |publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited |last=Hogan |first=Michael |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160117155403/http://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/oct/16/the-10-best-fictional-chefs-bradley-cooper-burnt-tv-film-screen-artie-bucco-ratatouille-soup-nazi |archivedate=January 17, 2016 |df= }} a trend that nearly coincides with her constant rotation of boyfriends in an ongoing search for the "perfect match".{{cite web|url=http://www.britannica.com/topic/Friends#ref1173760 |title=Friends |date= |accessdate=October 19, 2015 |website=Encyclopædia Britannica |publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica, Inc |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905120748/http://www.britannica.com/topic/Friends |archivedate=September 5, 2015 |df= }} Michael Hogan of ''[[The Guardian]]'' believes that the character's "competitive, perfectionist, obsessive-compulsive nature made her ideally suited to a career as a chef." However, her love of cooking and food is also responsible for her having been extremely [[overweight]] as a child, throughout high school and college.{{cite web|url=http://feminspire.com/fat-amy-monica-and-plus-size-women-in-mainstream-media/ |title=Fat Amy, Monica and Plus-Size Women in Mainstream Media |date=November 15, 2012 |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=Feminspire |publisher=Feminspire Media Network, LLC |last=Tarver |first=Emma |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150809173753/http://feminspire.com/fat-amy-monica-and-plus-size-women-in-mainstream-media |archivedate=August 9, 2015 |df= }} The [[running gag]] of an overweight Monica is often used as a recurring [[backstory]] for the character throughout the series,{{cite web|url=http://www.xojane.com/issues/friends-fat-monica-and-me |title=The One With All The Fat Jokes, or How Fat Monica on "Friends" Stuck With Me All These Years |date=March 2, 2015 |accessdate=September 10, 2015 |website=xoJane |publisher=Say Media, Inc |last=Kirby |first=Megan |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150919002108/http://www.xojane.com/issues/friends-fat-monica-and-me |archivedate=September 19, 2015 |df= }} first explored in the second-season episode "[[The One with the Prom Video|The One With the Prom Video]]" via [[Flashback episode|flashback]].{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jarettwieselman/funniest-friends-episodes#.ky210oAYW |title=The 15 Funniest "Friends" Episodes |date=December 31, 2014 |accessdate=September 15, 2015 |website=BuzzFeed |publisher=BuzzFeed, Inc |last=Wieselman |first=Jarrett |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905165442/http://www.buzzfeed.com/jarettwieselman/funniest-friends-episodes |archivedate=September 5, 2015 |df= }}{{Cite book|title = Transgressive Bodies: Representations in Film and Popular Culture|last = Richardson|first = Niall|publisher = Ashgate Publishing, Ltd|year = 2012|isbn = 9781409492689|location = United Kingdom|page = 83|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Zriz2REfgUAC&pg=PA83&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false}} One of the character's childhood nicknames was "Big Fat Goalie" when she played [[field hockey]].{{cite web|url=http://www.avclub.com/article/why-ifriendsi-fake-game-show-epitomized-ensemble-c-84632 |title=Why Friends’ fake game show epitomized ensemble comedy |date=September 6, 2012 |accessdate=September 17, 2015 |website=The A.V. Club |publisher=Onion Inc |last=Adams |first=Erik |last2=Bowman |first2=Donna |first3=Phil |last3=Dyess-Nugent |last4=Koski |first4=Genevieve |last5=McGee |first5=Ryan |last6=Murray |first6=Noel |last7=VanDerWerff |first7=Todd |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150917125733/http://www.avclub.com/article/why-ifriendsi-fake-game-show-epitomized-ensemble-c-84632 |archivedate=September 17, 2015 |df= }} While overweight, Monica is depicted as having very low self-esteem, [[binge eating]] often, and constantly seeking attention. While in college, Monica is embarrassed into losing weight permanently after overhearing her then-crush Chandler make fun of her appearance.{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2015/01/24/chandlers_treatment_of_his_gay_father_is_appalling_everything_critics_realized_while_watching_friends_in_2015/ |title="Chandler’s treatment of his gay father is appalling": Everything critics realized while watching "Friends" in 2015 |date=January 23, 2015 |accessdate=September 10, 2015 |website=Salon |publisher=Salon Media Group, Inc |last=Silman |first=Anna |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909162343/http://www.salon.com/2015/01/24/chandlers_treatment_of_his_gay_father_is_appalling_everything_critics_realized_while_watching_friends_in_2015/ |archivedate=September 9, 2015 |df= }} ''Media and the Rhetoric of Body Perfection: Cosmetic Surgery, Weight Loss and Beauty in Popular Culture'' author Dr. Deborah Harris-Moore believes that Monica's tendency to come off as a [[control freak]] originates from her childhood struggles with weight gain, explaining that the character ate excessively in order "to cope with her emotions."{{Cite book|title = Media and the Rhetoric of Body Perfection: Cosmetic Surgery, Weight Loss and Beauty in Popular Culture|last = Harris-Moore|first = Deborah|publisher = Ashgate Publishing|year = 2014|isbn = 9781409469469|location = United Kingdom|page = 93|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=1Fa8AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA93&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false}} Possessing a very strong will, the character tends to exhibit outstanding perseverance when it comes to what she expects out of her relationships, jobs, and life in general, oftentimes refusing to settle for anything less than what satisfies her. Early in the series, Monica develops a reputation for experiencing bad luck and encountering rather unfortunate circumstances when it comes to dating, romantic relationships, and her love life. [[Nick at Nite]] joked that the character "likes to keep things tidy in her home and love life, although the latter is a bit more difficult." This motif is frequently explored as a source of comic relief; the character's friends would often "pick apart" her new dates and boyfriends. In his review of the series, David Hiltbrand of ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' referred to the character as "an unlucky-in-love [[codependent]],"{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20104006,00.html |title=Picks and Pans Main: Tube |date=October 3, 1994 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=People |publisher=Time Inc |last=Hiltbrand |first=David |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907030930/http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0%2C%2C20104006%2C00.html |archivedate=September 7, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} while the ''Chicago Tribune''{{'}}s Ken Parish Perkins observed that Monica "often misfires when shooting for Mr. Right." According to Mike D'Avria of [[Splitsider]], Monica "never shied away from jumping into the sac with both random guys and people she worked with" – among them a high school senior, an old high school crush, and an alcoholic – prior to dating Chandler, and of the show's six main characters maintains the highest total of [[serious relationship]]s.{{Cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2011/07/the-sexual-proclivities-of-friends/ |title=The Sexual Proclivities of Friends |date=July 27, 2011 |access-date=January 17, 2015 |website=Splitsider |publisher= |last=D'Avria |first=Mike |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150408041121/http://splitsider.com/2011/07/the-sexual-proclivities-of-friends |archivedate=April 8, 2015 |df= }} Cox described Monica as goofy, angry, and sarcastic, while referring to her as the show's most sexually active character despite her "goody two shoes" image. Out of ''Friends''' female characters, Monica's style took the longest to establish. ''[[InStyle]]'' wrote that Monica's combination of short, wavy hair and dark lipstick evoked "a '90s take on '40s style."{{cite web|url=http://www.instyle.com/celebrity/transformations/courteney-coxs-changing-looks#4918 |title=Courteney Cox's Changing Looks |date= |accessdate=October 6, 2015 |website=InStyle |publisher= |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151006130821/http://www.instyle.com/celebrity/transformations/courteney-coxs-changing-looks |archivedate=October 6, 2015 |df= }} Ashley Hoffman of ''[[Dan Abrams|Styleite]]'' believes that character initially "dressed like a tourist trying to look like a New Yorker," frequently sporting jeans, overalls, and [[cargo shorts]].{{cite web|url=http://www.styleite.com/features/friends-fashion-used-to-be-real-until-it-wasnt/ |title=Friends Fashion Used to Be Real, Until It Wasn’t |date=May 7, 2014 |accessdate=September 18, 2015 |website=Styleite |publisher=Styleite, LLC |last=Hoffman |first=Ashley |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912051719/http://www.styleite.com/features/friends-fashion-used-to-be-real-until-it-wasnt/ |archivedate=September 12, 2015 |df= }} With a wardrobe comprised almost equally of dresses and pants, Monica's fashion sense, much like Rachel and Phoebe's, "was a little bit [[normcore]], a little bit [[Corporate casual|corporate-casual]]."{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2015/06/50-of-the-best-outfits-from-friends.html |title=50 of the Best Outfits From All 10 Seasons of Friends |date=August 11, 2015 |accessdate=September 18, 2015 |website=New York |publisher=New York Media LLC |last=Ceron |first=Ella |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150914075748/http://nymag.com/thecut/2015/06/50-of-the-best-outfits-from-friends.html |archivedate=September 14, 2015 |df= }} == Critical reception == Four months before its premiere, ''Friends'' failed NBC's confidential [[research report]], which cited the unlikeability of its six main characters as a possible factor.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesmokinggun.com/documents/crime/nbcs-failing-grade-friends |title=NBC's Failing Grade For "Friends" |date=May 10, 2004 |accessdate=September 17, 2015 |website=The Smoking Gun |publisher=TSG Industries Inc |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150915045700/http://www.thesmokinggun.com/documents/crime/nbcs-failing-grade-friends |archivedate=September 15, 2015 |df= }} Although the report acknowledged Monica as the only character with whom [[test audience]]s identified somewhat positively,{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,637211,00.html |title=Friends Flunked Its First Time Out |date=May 13, 2004 |accessdate=September 17, 2015 |website=People |publisher=Time Inc |last= |first= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151006123838/http://www.people.com/people/article/0%2C%2C637211%2C00.html |archivedate=October 6, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} NBC admitted that reception towards the character was "well below desirable levels for a lead" nonetheless.{{cite web|url = https://newrepublic.com/article/119434/friends-20th-anniversary-nbc-sitcoms-legacy|title = 'Not Very Entertaining, Clever, or Original": How NBC Almost Killed 'Friends'|date = September 12, 2014|accessdate = September 17, 2015|website = The New Republic|publisher = The New Republic|last = Harrison|first = Andrew}} In [[Retrospective|retrospect]], ''[[The New Republic|The New Republic's]]'' Andrew Harrison believes that although Monica and her friends "were superficial, self-absorbed
