and at first difficult to like ... in their solipsism and neurosis they reflected and sent up the world emerging around them ... far more accurately than any conventional gooey-hearted family sitcom", ultimately "creat[ing] a coffee-scented cocoon that millions wanted to enter". Reviews gradually improved; an early critical evaluation of ''Friends'', which had pegged Cox as the show's star, read, "As Monica, [Cox] came across as charming, attractive, confident, and motivated – the leader of the group". While men found the actress attractive, women appreciated her sense of humor. When ''Friends'' premiered in September 1994, critics initially perceived Monica as the show's main character; ''[[Entertainment Weekly|Entertainment Weekly's]]'' [[Ken Tucker]] attributes this to the fact that Cox was the show's most famous cast member at the time. The actress has garnered largely positive reviews for her performance, with Tucker concluding that Cox successfully "plays straight woman ... with alluring modesty". Tony Scott of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' commended the entire cast for "appear[ing] resourceful and display[ing] sharp sitcom skills ... especially Cox",{{cite web|url = https://variety.com/1994/tv/reviews/friends-4-1200438471/|title = Review: ''Friends''|date = September 22, 1994|accessdate = August 11, 2015|website = Variety|publisher = Variety Media, LLC|last = Scott|first = Tony|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150703012436/http://variety.com/1994/tv/reviews/friends-4-1200438471/|archivedate = July 3, 2015}} while ''[[The Baltimore Sun|The Baltimore Sun's]]'' [[David Zurawik]] described her acting as "terrific".{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/tv/bal-friends-94review-story.html |title=Good 'Friends' fits snugly into NBC's lineup |date=September 22, 1994 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=The Baltimore Sun |publisher=The Baltimore Sun |last=Zurawik |first=David |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402150057/http://www.baltimoresun.com/entertainment/tv/bal-friends-94review-story.html |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }} John Kiesewetter of ''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]'' praised Cox's ability to "deliver both verbal and physical comedy".{{cite web|url = http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2002/01/27/tem_friends_grows_in.html|title = 'Friends' grows in stature, ratings|date = January 27, 2002|accessdate = August 26, 2015|website = The Cincinnati Enquirer|publisher = news.cincinnati.com|last = Kiesewetter|first = John}} [[Contactmusic.com]]'s Sophie Miskiw commended Cox for portraying Monica with "endearing [[neurosis]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.contactmusic.com/jennifer-aniston/news/friends-alternate-cast-jennifer-aniston_4079951 |title=FRIENDS: The Stars Who Auditioned For Monica, Ross, Rachel, Chandler and Joey. character, [[Lifetime (TV network)|Lifetime]] described Monica as "neurotic yet lovable".{{cite web|url = http://www.mylifetime.com/movies/talhotblond/courteney-cox-biography|title = Courteney Cox's can't imagine why anyone wouldn't want to be Monica Geller", describing her as a "smart" and "savvy" character.{{Cite web|url=http://www.bustle.com/articles/44715-13-signs-you-are-the-monica-of-your-friend-group |title=13 Signs You Are The Monica Of Your Friend Group |date=October 20, 2014 |access-date=January 19, is "probably not our favourite character", [[TalkTalk Group|TalkTalk]] described the character as "wonderfully neurotic",{{cite web|url=http://www.talktalk.co.uk/celebrity/biography/person/courtney-cox/42 |title=Courtney Cox – Biography |date= |accessdate=September 19, 2015 |website=TalkTalk |publisher=TalkTalk |last= |first= reviewed her as "just as lovable as she is neurotic" despite her overbearing personality. Howard Rosenberg of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' was receptive towards the entire cast, especially Cox and her character, both of whom he described as "strong" and "likable and funny".{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1994-09-22/entertainment/ca-41409_1_martin-short-show |title=TV Reviews : NBC's Strongest Evening of the Week Has Its Weak Spot |date=September 22, 1994 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=Los Angeles Times |publisher=Los Angeles Times |last=Rosenberg |first=Howard |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402092239/http://articles.latimes.com/1994-09-22/entertainment/ca-41409_1_martin-short-show |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df= }} Also writing for the ''Los Angeles Times'', Glenn Whipp lauded Cox's tenure on ''Friends'', enthusing that the actress successfully "took a character loaded with obsessive-compulsive quirks and a goofy, overly competitive nature and fashioned a flesh-and-blood woman". Describing the actress' [[comic timing]] as "impeccable", Whipp went on to write that Cox "brought out Monica's insecurities in a way that turned [[self-deprecation]] into an art form". Jenna Mullins of [[E!]] dubbed Cox "a fantastic comedic actress".{{Cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/344541/snubbed-10-amazing-tv-actors-who-ve-never-won-an-emmy |title=Snubbed! 10 Amazing TV ''[[The Birmingham News]]'' described Monica as a "very, very funny" character.{{cite web|url=http://www.al.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2015/01/courteney_coxs_favorite_plus_1.html |title=Courteney Cox's favorite, plus 10 more great episodes of 'Friends' featuring Monica |date=January 5, 2015 |accessdate=September 15, 2015 |website=The Birmingham News |publisher=Alabama Media Group |last=Harvey |df= }} Kayla Upadhyaya of ''[[The Michigan Daily]]'' appreciated the fact that "Cox brought moments of sincerity and severity to Monica".{{cite performance as "degrading",{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2014/09/freinds-premiere-20-years-838313/ |title=Flashback: ‘Friends’ Premiered 20 Years Ago Today |date=September 22, 2014 |accessdate=August 11, 2015 |website=Deadline.com |publisher=Penske Business Media, LLC |last=Andreeva |first=Nellie |deadurl=no as a "fairly normal, but boring" character.{{cite web|url = http://screencrush.com/friends-at-20/|title = ''Friends'' At 20: Less Really is More|date = September 19, 2014|accessdate = September 17, 2015|website = ScreenCrush|publisher = Townsquare Media, Inc|last = Ryan|first = Mike|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150925091919/http://screencrush.com/friends-at-20/|archivedate = September 25, 2015}} In 1999, Cox was nominated for an [[American Comedy Awards|American Comedy Award for Funniest Supporting Female Performer in a TV Series]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/person/15465/Courteney-Cox/biography |title=Courteney Cox – Full Biography |date= |accessdate=August 24, 2015 |website=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |last=Cooper |first=Tracie |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926065755/http://www.nytimes.com/movies/person/15465/Courteney-Cox/biography |archivedate=September 26, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://pop-culture.net/C/Courtney-Cox-Arquette.html |title=Courteney Cox Arquette |date= |accessdate=August 26, 2015 |website=Pop Culture.net |publisher= |last= |first= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925092011/http://pop-culture.net/C/Courtney-Cox-Arquette.html |archivedate=September 25, 2015 |df= }} Although continuously praised for her performance, Cox never received an [[Emmy Award]] nomination for her role on ''Friends'' during its entire run, although each of her five co-stars did.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cheatsheet.com/entertainment/10-amazing-tv-stars-who-have-never-won-an-emmy.html/?a=viewall |title=10 Big TV Stars Who Have Never Won an Emmy |date=March 28, 2015 |access-date=January 16, 2015 |website=The Cheat Sheet |publisher=The Cheat Sheet |last=Regalado |first=Michelle |deadurl=no female castmates Lisa Kudrow and Jennifer Aniston remain the show's only main cast members to have won the award, whose multiple nominations Cox especially "had a hard time not taking ... personally", admitting to having been "hurt" by the snub.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/gallery/emmys-biggest-snubs-steve-carell-632433/13-courteney-cox |title=Emmys' Biggest Snubs: Steve Carell, 2015 |df= }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.popsugar.com/entertainment/Actors-Who-Have-Never-Won-Emmys-35406088#photo-35413944 |title=9 People You Really Thought Had Emmys |date=September 17, 2015 |archivedate=February 1, 2016 |df= }} The [[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]]' failure to acknowledge Cox prompted Jenna Mullins of [[E!]] to ask "if Hollywood has something against honoring a fantastic comedic actress like Cox." In 2014, [[SheKnows Media]] published an article explaining five reasons author Rita Loiacono believes Monica is "the best character on ''Friends''", citing her cleanliness, bluntness and role as "the heart of the group", among others. Loiacono enthused that Monica "didn't just have one defining aspect; she had many, and they were all equally hilarious. Not to mention, her ambition and vulnerability resulted in some of the show's most touching and heartbreaking moments". Additionally, Loiacono dismissed the fact that Cox has never received an Emmy Award nomination for her performance as Monica as "downright criminal". In 2015, [[HitFix]] wrote a similar article entitled "5 Reasons Monica Geller is the Best ''Friends'' Friend", published in tandem with Cox's 51 birthday.{{cite web|url = http://www.hitfix.com/the-dartboard/5-reasons-monica-geller-is-the-best-friends-friend|title = 5 Reasons Monica Geller is the Best ''Friends'' Friend|date = June 15, 2015|accessdate = September 8, 2015|website = HitFix|publisher = HitFix, Inc|last = Libson|first = Zara|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150925124911/http://www.hitfix.com/the-dartboard/5-reasons-monica-geller-is-the-best-friends-friend|archivedate = September 25, 2015}} An article in ''[[The Birmingham News]]'' cited "[[The Pilot (Friends)|The One Where it All Began]]", "[[The One with Two Parts (1)|The One With Two Parts: Part 2]]", "[[The One with the Prom Video]]", "[[Friends (season 4)|The One with Chandler in a Box]]", "[[The One with the Embryos]]", "[[The One with All the Thanksgivings]]", "[[Friends (season 5)|The One Where Everybody Finds Out]]", "[[Friends (season 6)|The One On the Last Night]]", "[[The One with the Proposal]]", "[[The One with Monica and Chandler's Wedding]]" and "[[The Last One (Friends)|The Last One]]" among Monica's best episodes; Cox herself acknowledged "The One with the Embryos" as her personal favorite. Meanwhile, [[Boston.com|BDCwire]] ranked "The One with the Routine", "The One with the Cheap Wedding Dress", "The One with Monica's Boots", "The One with the Jellyfish" and "The One Where Monica Sings" among the character's best.{{cite web|url=http://www.bdcwire.com/a-definitive-ranking-of-the-5-best-friends-episodes-for-each-character/ |title=A Definitive Ranking of the 5 Best ''Friends'' Episodes for Each Character |date=January 6, 2015 |accessdate=September 15, 2015 |website=BDCwire |publisher=The Boston Globe |last=Leist |first=Christie |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150815010104/http://www.bdcwire.com/a-definitive-ranking-of-the-5-best-friends-episodes-for-each-character/ |archivedate=August 15, 2015 |df= }} Despite consistently warm reception towards Cox and her character, some aspects of Monica's characterization have been criticized. The [[Friends (season 2)|second season]] episode "[[The One Where Dr. Ramoray Dies]]" sparked controversy due to one of its storylines revolving around Monica and Rachel arguing over which roommate will win the last remaining condom in their apartment in order to have sex with their respective boyfriends, Richard and Ross. In her book ''Narratives, Health, and Healing: Communication Theory, Research, and Practice'', author Lynn M. Harter defended the storyline, arguing that it promotes [[safe sex]].{{Cite book|title = Narratives, Health, and Healing: Communication Theory, Research, and Practice|last = Harter|first = Lynn M|publisher = Routledge|year = 2006|isbn = 9781135610982|location = United Kingdom|page = 177|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=l6uRAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA177&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false|last2 = Japp|first2 = Phyllis M|last3 = Beck|first3 = Christina S}} Rachel eventually wins the condom in a game of [[rock, paper, scissors]], forcing Monica to abstain for the night. Monica's overweight [[alter ego|alter-ego]] "Fat Monica" has often been accused of being an offensive stereotype of overweight women exploited for laughs. Although identifying a formerly overweight character as "a standard TV [[Trope (literature)|trope]]", the ''[[New Statesman|New Statesman's]]'' Bim Adewunmi wrote that Fat Monica "always struck a weird note" with the writer despite the show's efforts "to pinpoint a solid and satisfying back-story for the character".{{cite web|url=http://www.newstatesman.com/culture/2013/04/friends-gone-good-could-we-be-any-sadder |title=Friends is gone for good. Could we BE any sadder? |date=April 18, 2013 |accessdate=September 17, 2015 |website=New Statesman |publisher=New Statesman |last=Adewunmi |first=Bim |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130804071729/http://www.newstatesman.com/culture/2013/04/friends-gone-good-could-we-be-any-sadder |archivedate=August 4, 2013 |df= }} Megan Kirby of [[xoJane]] questioned the negative effect the show's [[fat jokes]] would have on its overweight viewers, writing, "What does this mean for the girls like me who never become thin? Are we relegated to side roles and stereotypes in our own lives? Of course, this isn’t true. But I think it sometimes, dark and secret: The fat girl doesn’t get to be the protagonist." Emma Tarver of Feminspire reflected that Fat Monica "made me think as a child that I was unworthy of love, was going to be mocked relentlessly by my friends and family for my weight, and should never bother flirting because I would just disgust every man I looked at." Contrarily, Kelsey Miller of [[Refinery29]] received Fat Monica positively as "proof I could overcome my disgusting plumpness and be seen as lovable, too". In spite of these complaints, Fat Monica proved so popular among audiences that the writers would resurrect the character for a total of four [[flashback episode]]s, each of which aired featuring Cox dressed as Fat Monica and eating a [[doughnut]] while dancing after the show had finished taping much to the amusement of the studio audience. Although she only appears physically in four, Fat Monica is referenced in approximately half of the show's episodes, and has since proven popular enough to be adapted into an [[internet meme]]. == Impact and legacy == While each main character eventually evolved into household names the longer ''Friends'' ran, the once-obscure actors by whom they were portrayed gradually established themselves as celebrities. According to ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]'', the combined popularity of Monica and Cox established them both as [[cultural icon|television icons]] during the 1990s.{{Cite news |url=http://courteneycox.org/articles/Elle.pdf |title=best friends girl |last=Dawson |first=Jeff |work=Elle |access-date=August 13, 2015 |via= |pages=92–96 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150714020359/http://courteneycox.org/articles/Elle.pdf |archivedate=July 14, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/courteney-cox/bio/189723/ |title=Courteney Cox |date= |accessdate=September 19, 2015 |website=TV Guide |publisher=CBS Interactive Inc |last= |first= |quote=Cox became a small-screen icon as sweet, if uptight, neat freak Monica Geller on the beloved, decade-long sitcom ''Friends''. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150909010617/http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/courteney-cox/bio/189723/ |archivedate=September 9, 2015 |df= }} Additionally, [[List of most popular given names|baby name]] books now commonly associate the name "Monica" with the character.{{Cite book|title = 5-Star Baby Name Advisor|last = Lansky|first = Bruce|publisher = Simon and Schuster|year = 2011|isbn = 9781451620238|location = United States|pages = |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=eNJX65OvHfkC&pg=PT334&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false}} As the role in which Cox "found fame", Monica remains the actress' most iconic role to-date, as well as the part for which she remains best known.{{cite web|url=http://www.infoplease.com/biography/var/courteneycox.html |title=Courteney Cox |date= |accessdate=August 25, 2015 |website=Infoplease |publisher=Sandbox Networks, Inc |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905202112/http://www.infoplease.com/biography/var/courteneycox.html |archivedate=September 5, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|url = https://web.archive.org/web/20151019041020/http://www.ign.com/stars/courteney-cox|archivedate = October 19, 2015}} ''[[Us Weekly]]'' believes that Cox "made television history during her 10 year stint playing Monica".{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrities/courteney-cox/biography|title=Courteney Cox|last=|first=|date=|website=Us Weekly|publisher=Us Weekly|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906003641/http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrities/courteney-cox/biography|archivedate=September 6, 2015|deadurl=|accessdate=August 25, 2015|df=}} Meanwhile, Steve Weinstein of the ''Los Angeles Times'' credits Cox's comedic performance with helping disprove the stereotype that "Pretty women aren't supposed to be funny". In 1995, one year after ''Friends'' premiered, Cox appeared on the cover of ''[[People (magazine)|People's]]'' "[[50 Most Beautiful People]]". According to ''Alabama Biographical Dictionary'' author Jan Onofrio, Monica helped "put [Cox] in the television spotlight and provided offers for more desirable roles."{{Cite book|title = Alabama Biographical Dictionary|last = Onofrio|first = Jan|publisher = Somerset Publishers|year = 1998|isbn = 9780403098118|location = United States|page = 91|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=S3GLWEaxpVYC&pg=PA91&dq=monica+geller+friends#v=onepage&q=monica%20geller%20friends&f=false}} The ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]'' referred to Cox as "one of the more successful 'Friends' since the show ended" thanks in part to her subsequent television and film roles.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/friends-gallery-1.90286?pmSlide=1.91000 |title='Friends': Where are they now? |accessdate=August 12, 2015 |website=Daily News |publisher= |last=Sloame |first=Joanna |last2=Salvatore |first2=Rosanne |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150707102900/http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/friends-gallery-1.90286?pmSlide=1.91000 |archivedate=July 7, 2015 |df= }} According to Reed Tucker of the ''New York Post'', "Cox has diversified perhaps more than her former co-stars" by founding her own production company [[Coquette Productions]], exploring directing and obtaining a [[real estate license]].{{Cite web|url=https://nypost.com/2014/05/04/10-years-later-how-do-the-friends-stack-up/ |title=10 years later, how do the ‘Friends’ stack up? |date=May 4, 2014 |accessdate=October 26, 2015 |website=New York Post |publisher=NYC Holdings, Inc |last=Tucker |first=Reed |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151025082654/http://nypost.com/2014/05/04/10-years-later-how-do-the-friends-stack-up/ |archivedate=October 25, 2015 |df= }} However, the actress has also been criticized for failing to venture into roles that differ from Monica. By both starring in and producing the sitcom ''[[Cougar Town]]'', which has been reviewed as the actress' "best gig since'' ... Friends''",{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/03/AR2009090303757.html |title=Fall TV Preview: Tom Shales and Hank Stuever Run Down Shows From Best to Worst |date=September 6, 2009 |accessdate=October 26, 2015 |website=The Washington Post |publisher=The Washington Post |last=Stuever |first=Hank |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150627171805/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/03/AR2009090303757.html |archivedate=June 27, 2015 |df= }} Cox became the only ''Friends'' main cast member to accomplish significant television success post-''Friends''.{{cite web|url=http://splitsider.com/2011/01/the-legacy-of-friends-or-lack-thereof/ |title=The Legacy of Friends — Or Lack Thereof |date=January 11, 2011 |accessdate=September 17, 2015 |website=Splitsider |publisher= |last=Kurp |first=Joshua |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403112304/http://splitsider.com/2011/01/the-legacy-of-friends-or-lack-thereof/ |archivedate=April 3, 2015 |df= }} According to ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'', Hollywood professionals voted Monica the 47th best fictional female character.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/50-best-female-characters-entertainment-industry-survey-results-951483/item/monica-geller-friends-50-favorite-female-characters-951493|title=Hollywood's 50 Favorite Female Characters|last=|first=|date=December 9, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=July 25, 2017}} [[ChaCha (search engine)|ChaCha]] collectively ranked Phoebe, Rachel and Monica the 11th, 12th and 13th best female television characters of all-time, respectively.{{cite web|url = http://www.chacha.com/gallery/1276/top-16-female-tv-characters-of-all-time/7695|title = Top 16 Female TV Characters of All Time|date = |accessdate = September 19, 2015|website = ChaCha|publisher = ChaCha Search, Inc|last = |first = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150702040742/http://www.chacha.com/gallery/1276/top-16-female-tv-characters-of-all-time/7695|archivedate = July 2, 2015}} Maria Tallarico of ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'' observed that a number of Monica's storylines, specifically one in which the character unintentionally has sex with a [[high school senior]], "probably wouldn't fly on TV today". Writing for [[Mic.com]], Samantha Allen believes that Monica helped "set the standard for how sitcoms could and would talk about sex" by both engaging in [[casual sex]] and [[Age difference in sexual relationships|dating a much older man]].{{cite web|url = http://mic.com/articles/98732/the-best-reason-to-love-friends-is-the-one-we-never-realized-at-the-time|title = The Best Reason to Love 'Friends' Is the One We Never Realized at the Time|date = September 12, 2014|accessdate = September 10, 2015|website = Mic.com|publisher = |last = Allen|first = Samantha}} According to Dustin Levy of ''[[The Diamondback]]'', Monica inspired "any ensemble cast in a sitcom with a female character who is bossy or neurotic," citing ''[[Scrubs (TV series)|Scrubs]]''’ [[Elliot Reid]] and ''[[Happy Endings (TV series)|Happy Endings]]''’ Jane Kerkovich-Williams as examples of Monica's influence. Additionally, Levy identified [[Claire Dunphy]] from the sitcom ''[[Modern Family]]'' as Monica's modern-day equivalent, explaining that the character "acts like Monica plus children". In spring 2015, ''[[TV Guide]]'' published an article entitled "22 Spring Cleaning Tips From Monica Geller" in recognition of the character's cleanliness.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/news/friends-spring-cleaning-tips-monica-geller/ |title=22 Spring Cleaning Tips From Monica Geller |date=April 21, 2015 |accessdate=September 18, 2015 |website=TV Guide |publisher=CBS Interactive Inc |last=Eng |first=Joyce |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150912045500/http://www.tvguide.com/news/friends-spring-cleaning-tips-monica-geller/ |archivedate=September 12, 2015 |df= }} In her article "5 Signs You’re A Real-Life Monica Geller", Ayn Bernos of ''[[Thought Catalog]]'' wrote that the character's personality is the reason "all perfectionist fans of this iconic TV show have asked themselves this question at least once in their life: 'Oh my god, am I a Monica Geller?!'" Emma Lord of ''[[Bustle (magazine)|Bustle]]'' expounded in her article "13 Signs You Are The Monica Of Your Friend Group" "that isn't to say life is easy for the Real Life Monicas of the world. First, there's all the name calling: 'neat freak' and 'sore loser', to name a few. Second, all of your elaborate, carefully-laid plans inevitably go haywire when people around you don't respect the obvious beauty and rightness of them." [[File:Monica's apartment.jpg|thumb|One of the show's main locations, Monica's apartment currently ranks among television's most famous sets.|297x297px]] ''Friends''{{'}} female characters had a profound influence on [[Womenswear|women's fashion]] during the 1990s,{{cite web|url=http://www.stylist.co.uk/fashion/friends-iconic-fashion-beauty-hair-wedding-moments#gallery-8 |title=The 50 most iconic fashion and beauty moments in Friends |date= |accessdate=September 18, 2015 |website=Stylist |publisher=Stylist |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150417094059/http://www.stylist.co.uk/fashion/friends-iconic-fashion-beauty-hair-wedding-moments |archivedate=April 17, 2015 |df= }} becoming household names as well as fashion icons.{{Cite web|url=http://www.msn.com/en-ca/entertainment/celebrity/remember-these-celebrity-crushes-look-at-them-now/ss-BBs48xy#image=14 |title=Remember these celebrity crushes? Look at them now! |last= |first= |date= |website=MSN.com |publisher=Microsoft |access-date=April 27, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424151257/http://www.msn.com/en-ca/entertainment/celebrity/remember-these-celebrity-crushes-look-at-them-now/ss-BBs48xy |archivedate=April 24, 2016 |df= }} Monica, Rachel and Phoebe each "became style icons for a generation of young women." According to Desiree Tolentino of ''[[University of Nevada Press|Verge Campus]]'', "Rachel and Monica were THE fashion icons back in the day", writing, "Monica Geller’s vivacious style and [[Sexual attraction|sex appeal]] inspires every girl to care just a little bit more about what they wear, even if it’s moving boxes from one apartment to the other."{{Cite web|url=http://vergecampus.com/2016/02/looking-back-rachel-and-monicas-fashion-trends-from-friends/ |title=Looking Back: Rachel and Monica’s Fashion Trends from Friends |last=Tolentino |first=Desiree |date= |website=Verge Campus |publisher= |access-date=December 15, 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160522182041/http://vergecampus.com/2016/02/looking-back-rachel-and-monicas-fashion-trends-from-friends/ |archivedate=May 22, 2016 |df= }} Describing Monica's wardrobe as "classic and elegant", ''[[Stylist (magazine)|Stylist]]'' observed that the character's first season [[bob cut]] was imitated by several woman, although its popularity paled in comparison to that of Aniston's iconic "[[The Rachel|Rachel]]" haircut, the widespread success of which Cox was jealous.{{cite web|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2014/09/courteney-cox-jennifer-aniston-friends-rachel-haircut |title=Courteney Cox Was Envious of Jennifer Aniston’s "Rachel" Haircut on Friends |date=September 23, 2014 |accessdate=September 18, 2015 |website=Vanity Fair |publisher=Condé Nast |last=Duboff |first=Josh |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150921182732/http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2014/09/courteney-cox-jennifer-aniston-friends-rachel-haircut |archivedate=September 21, 2015 |df= }} However, ''Cosmopolitan'' identified Monica's hairstyle as "Iconic in its own right", including in its list of "20 iconic Friends hairstyles".{{Cite web|url = http://www.cosmopolitan.co.uk/beauty-hair/celebrity-hair-makeup/news/g3720/iconic-friends-hairstyles/?slide=7|title = 20 iconic Friends hairstyles|date = |access-date = January 17, 2016|website = Cosmopolitan|publisher = Hearst Magazines UK|last = |first = }} Monica also became well known for accessorizing sweaters using scarves; on Cox's 51 birthday in 2015, ''Cosmopolitan'' published an article celebrating her character's best sweaters.{{cite web|url = http://www.cosmopolitan.com.au/fashion/fashion-trends/2015/6/9-times-monica-geller-jumper-/?pId=29/|title = 9 times Monica Gellar's jumper game was strong|date = June 16, 2015|accessdate = September 18, 2015|website = Cosmopolitan|publisher = Bauer Media Pty Limited|last = |first = |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151019035128/http://www.cosmopolitan.com.au/fashion/fashion-trends/2015/6/9-times-monica-geller-jumper/|archivedate = October 19, 2015}} [[BuzzFeed]] ranked Monica's wedding dress seventh on the website's list of the "28 TV Show Wedding Dresses You’ll Always Envy",{{cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/kayesss/33-of-the-most-memorable-tv-wedding-dresses-ever-k1bt#.ide0KnNR8 |title=28 TV Show Wedding Dresses You’ll Always Envy |date=June 15, 2015 |accessdate=September 14, 2015 |website=BuzzFeed |publisher=BuzzFeed, Inc |last=Smith |first=Katie Louise |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150918063458/http://www.buzzfeed.com/kayesss/33-of-the-most-memorable-tv-wedding-dresses-ever-k1bt |archivedate=September 18, 2015 |df= }} while ''[[Brides (magazine)|Brides]]'' ranked it the ninth greatest wedding dress in television history.{{cite web|url=http://www.brides.com/celebrity-wedding/2014/06/best-tv-wedding-dresses#slide=9 |title=The Best TV Wedding Dresses Monica on Friends |date= |accessdate=September 14, 2015 |website=Brides |publisher=Condé Nast |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170105174018/http://www.brides.com/gallery/best-tv-wedding-dresses |archivedate=January 5, 2017 |df= }} ''Us Weekly'' included it on their list of "Celebrity Wedding Dresses: TV & Movies".{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-style/pictures/celebrity-wedding-dresses-tv-and-movies-2012175/22586 |title=Celebrity Wedding Dresses: TV & Movies |date= |accessdate=September 14, 2015 |website=Us Weekly |publisher=Us Weekly |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150913010500/http://www.usmagazine.com/celebrity-style/pictures/celebrity-wedding-dresses-tv-and-movies-2012175/22586 |archivedate=September 13, 2015 |df= }} Meanwhile, ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' cited several of Monica's outfits and hairstyles among the newspaper's list of "Friends best fashion moments".{{cite web|url=http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG11107704/Friends-20th-anniversary-the-best-fashion-moments.html |title=Friends best fashion moments |date=September 21, 2014 |accessdate=September 21, 2015 |website=The Daily Telegraph |publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited |last=White |first=Belinda |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150308204035/http://fashion.telegraph.co.uk/article/TMG11107704/Friends-20th-anniversary-the-best-fashion-moments.html |archivedate=March 8, 2015 |df= }} According to Patricia Murphy of the ''[[Irish Independent]]'', Monica "is most definitely one of the most famous fictional telly chefs," expounding, "her OCD combined with her continuous strive for perfection making her a thoroughly enjoyable watch."{{Cite web|url = http://www.independent.ie/life/food-drink/table-talk/turn-up-the-heat-top-10-fictional-chefs-30380286.html|title = Turn up the heat: Top 10 Fictional Chefs|date = June 24, 2014|access-date = January 18, 2015|website = Irish Independent|publisher = Independent.ie|last = Murphy|first = Patricia}} ''[[The Guardian]]'' ranked Monica fifth on the newspaper's list of "The 10 best fictional chefs", while ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' ranked the character eighth, with author Grace Gavilanes writing, "She's the best kind of chef – neurotic in the most entertaining/productive way, and ''always'' cleans up the mess in her kitchen."{{Cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/greatideas/gallery/0,,20962024_30406016,00.html#30406012 |title=Food for Thought: Our Favorite Fictional Chefs of All Time – MONICA GELLER – FRIENDS |date=October 23, 2015 |access-date=January 18, 2016 |website=People |publisher=Time Inc |last=Gavilanes |first=Grace |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151029003502/http://www.people.com/people/greatideas/gallery/0%2C%2C20962024_30406016%2C00.html |archivedate=October 29, 2015 |df= }} ''[[USA Today]]'''s Robert Bianco credits Monica and Chandler's relationship and their wedding in the episode "[[The One with Monica and Chandler's Wedding|The One With Monica and Chandler's Wedding]]" with saving ''Friends''. Prior to the episode, the show had "appeared to be in serious danger of out-staying its welcome." Although admitting that the overall episode "is not one of ''Friends''' best", Bianco explained that "The wedding changed all that, and in remarkable fashion."{{Cite web|url = http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2004-04-21-revisiting-friends_x.htm|title = Monica and Chandler's wedding kept the honeymoon going strong|date = April 21, 2004|access-date = January 19, 2016|website = USA Today|publisher = Gannett Co. Inc.|last = Bianco|first = Robert}} While BuzzFeed ranked Monica and Chandler the 23rd best television couple,{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/fivezaj/the-50-best-tv-couples-a8zp |title=50 Best TV Couples Ever |date=May 4, 2013 |access-date=January 18, 2016 |website=BuzzFeed |publisher=BuzzFeed, Inc |last=Ivezaj |first=Flora |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150214100657/http://www.buzzfeed.com/fivezaj/the-50-best-tv-couples-a8zp |archivedate=February 14, 2015 |df= }} [[E!]] placed the couple second on its ranking of the greatest ''Friends'' couples, with author Sydney Bucksbaum writing, "It's hard to imagine a time when Monica and Chandler weren't together, but it took them four seasons to actually get together. From then on, it was clear that they were meant to be."{{Cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/ca/photos/13785/we-ranked-all-the-friends-couples-and-no-1-may-shock-you/418954 |title=We Ranked All the Friends Couples, and No. 1 May Shock You... – 2. Monica and Chandler |date= |access-date=January 18, 2016 |website=E! |publisher=Entertainment Television, LLC |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160527040208/http://www.eonline.com/ca/photos/13785/we-ranked-all-the-friends-couples-and-no-1-may-shock-you/418954 |archivedate=May 27, 2016 |df= }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.eonline.com/news/581519/we-ranked-all-the-friends-couples-and-no-1-may-shock-you |title=News/ We Ranked All the Friends Couples, and No. 1 May Shock You... |date=September 22, 2014 |access-date=January 18, 2016 |website=E! |publisher=Entertainment Television, Inc |last=Bucksbaum |first=Sydney |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160126102359/http://www.eonline.com/news/581519/we-ranked-all-the-friends-couples-and-no-1-may-shock-you |archivedate=January 26, 2016 |df= }} Tim Gerstenberger of [[TV Overmind]] echoed this sentiment by ranking Chandler Monica's best boyfriend, awarding him an 'A' grade. Gerstenberger penned, "I would not be able to face myself every day if I did not rank Chandler the best of Monica’s boyfriends from ''Friends.'' The two ended up getting married, which just goes to show that some one night stands are meant to last."{{Cite web|url=http://www.tvovermind.com/friends/best-worst-monicas-boyfriends-friends |title=The Best and Worst of Monica’s Boyfriends on ‘Friends’ |date=March 13, 2015 |access-date=January 18, 2016 |website=TV Overmind |publisher=TVOvermind |last=Gerstenberger |first=Tim |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160114234637/http://www.tvovermind.com/friends/best-worst-monicas-boyfriends-friends |archivedate=January 14, 2016 |df= }} Monica and Ross' relationship was also influential.{{Cite web|url=http://www.crushable.com/2014/01/19/entertainment/90s-tv-shows-best-siblings-list/2/ |title=A Definitive Ranking of ’90s TV Siblings |date=2014 |access-date=January 19, 2016 |website=Crushable |publisher=Defy Media, LLC |last=Langeslay |first=Ruby |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016204218/http://www.crushable.com/2014/01/19/entertainment/90s-tv-shows-best-siblings-list/2/ |archivedate=October 16, 2015 |df= }} According to Kriti Tulsiani of [[CNN-IBN|IBNLive]], the characters "provide a perfect exception to the myth that one cannot find a best friend in their sibling particularly when they are of opposite sex ... they have broken all the conventional boundaries of a brother-sister relationship." [[PopSugar]] ranked Monica and Ross fifth on the website's list of "The 9 Best Sibling Relationships From '90s TV"{{Cite web|url=http://www.popsugar.com/love/90s-TV-Show-Siblings-22603817#photo-22603842 |title=The 9 Best Sibling Relationships From '90s TV |date=April 10, 2014 |access-date=January 19, 2016 |website=PopSugar |publisher=POPSUGAR Inc |last=Meyers |first=Laura Marie |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151104101322/http://www.popsugar.com/love/90s-TV-Show-Siblings-22603817 |archivedate=November 4, 2015 |df= }} Immediately established as one of the show's primary settings, Monica's large [[Greenwich Village]] apartment has since become one of the most famous and iconic television sets in history.{{cite web|url=http://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/interiors-entertaining/advice/g4727/best-tv-apartments/?slide=4 |title=12 Best Apartments on TV |accessdate=August 10, 2015 |website=Harper's Bazaar |publisher=Hearst Communications, Inc |last= |first= |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151007162026/http://www.harpersbazaar.com/culture/interiors-entertaining/advice/g4727/best-tv-apartments/?slide=4 |archivedate=October 7, 2015 |df= }}{{Cite web |url=http://www.builddirect.com/blog/7-things-we-loved-about-friends-monica-gellers-apartment/ |title=7 Things We Loved About Friends’ Monica Geller’s Apartment |date=June 18, 2015 |accessdate=January 2, 2015 |website=BuildDirect |publisher=BuildDirect |last=Cameron |first=Steffani |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150822143958/http://www.builddirect.com/blog/7-things-we-loved-about-friends-monica-gellers-apartment/ |archivedate=August 22, 2015 |df= }} Steffani Cameron of [[BuildDirect]] wrote that Monica's "apartment was unlike anything else on TV. It was full of color, clutter, and personality. It was a space cobbled together of kitsch and class, and it was just magic", citing its windows, color and openness among her favourite things about the apartment. ''[[Harper's Bazaar]]'' magazine ranked it among the "12 Best Apartments on TV". Chloe Daley of [[Refinery29]] joked that the apartment serves as both "a lesson in how to decorate with purple" and "a lesson in how ''not'' to".{{cite web|url=http://www.refinery29.com/best-fictional-apartments#slide-11 |title=17 Iconic TV Show Apartments That Give Us Interior Inspiration |date=February 18, 2015 |accessdate=August 10, 2015 |website=Refinery29 |publisher=Refinery29 |last=Daley |first=Chloe |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140824184716/http://www.refinery29.com/best-fictional-apartments |archivedate=August 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Based on its total number of bedrooms, [[open kitchen]] concept, large living space and balcony, real estate agent Sydney Blumstein estimates that the apartment would be worth approximately {{USD}}2.3 million in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.refinery29.com/unrealistic-real-estate#slide-9 |title=The Real Cost Of 10 Iconic TV Show Apartments |date=April 1, 2015 |accessdate=August 10, 2015 |website=Refinery29 |publisher=Refinery29 |last=Ronan |first=Alex |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005070107/http://www.refinery29.com/unrealistic-real-estate |archivedate=October 5, 2015 |deadurl=yes |df= }} In terms of its size and affordability, the apartment has frequently been the subject of scrutiny; critics constantly question how Monica, a chef, and Rachel, a waitress, were able to afford such a luxurious home based on their relatively low incomes,{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/read/the-terrible-legacy-of-friends |title=How 'Friends' Created a Generation of Neurotic, Self-Obsessed Idiots |date=January 21, 2014 |accessdate=September 17, 2015 |website=Vice |publisher=VICE Media LLC |last=Martin |first=Clive |last2=Olah |first2=Natalie |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150918231655/http://www.vice.com/read/the-terrible-legacy-of-friends |archivedate=September 18, 2015 |df= }} often dismissing the show's explanation that this is due to an illegal [[sublet]] courtesy of Monica's grandmother who moved to Florida.{{cite web|url=http://www.villagevoice.com/blogs/the-five-most-unrealistic-apartments-on-tv-or-in-movies-6374922 |title=The Five Most Unrealistic Apartments On TV Or In Movies |date=March 26, 2012 |accessdate=August 10, 2015 |website=The Village Voice |publisher=Village Voice, LLC |last=Musto |first=Michael |quote=...the two-bedroom apartment isn't believable even with the explanation that it seems to be an illegal sublet. A struggling chef and a waitress couldn't possibly afford such an apartment. |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151005000654/http://www.villagevoice.com/blogs/the-five-most-unrealistic-apartments-on-tv-or-in-movies-6374922 |archivedate=October 5, 2015 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywood.com/general/tv-s-most-ridiculous-apartments-60078025/#/ms-7769/11 |title=TV’s Most Ridiculous Apartments |accessdate=August 10, 2015 |website=Hollywood.com |publisher=HOLLYWOOD.COM LLC |last=Stone |first=Abbey |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150731000630/http://www.hollywood.com/general/tv-s-most-ridiculous-apartments-60078025/ |archivedate=July 31, 2015 |df= }} [[Hollywood.com]]'s Abbey Stone ranked it television's 10th "most ridiculous" apartment, while ''[[The Village Voice]]'' placed it at number four in a similar article. == See also == * [[List of Friends characters|List of ''Friends'' characters]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Portal bar|Comedy|Fashion|Friends|Judaism|New York City|Television in the United States}} {{wikimedia|collapsible=yes|wikt=no|v=no|b=no|s=no|n=no|c=Category:Courteney Cox|d=Q719866}} {{Friends}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Geller, Monica}} [[Category:Fictional American Jews]] [[Category:Fictional chefs]] [[Category:Fictional characters from New York City]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1994]] [[Category:Friends characters]] [[Category:Fictional feminist characters]] [[Category:Female characters in television]] [[Category:Obsessive–compulsive disorder in fiction]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
[[File:Old Ashmolean 2006.JPG|thumb|The [[Old Ashmolean]] building in Oxford, an early example of purpose-built museum architecture]] [[File:Guggenheim museum exterior.jpg|thumb|The [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in New York City, designed by [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] and opened in 1959]]
'''Museum architecture'''<ref>{{cite book | title=The Architecture of the Museum: Symbolic Structures, Urban Contexts | publisher=[[Manchester University Press]] | year=2003 | isbn=978-0-7190-5610-9 | editor-last=Giebelhausen | editor-first=Michaela | series=Critical Perspectives in Art History}}</ref> has been of increasing importance over the centuries, especially more recently.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.globalprovince.com/museumarchitecture.htm | title=The Explosion of Museum Architecture | website=www.globalprovince.com | publisher=Global Province | year=2006 | accessdate=October 14, 2011 | last=Francis | first=Richard L.}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | title=Museums and the Maecenas Touch | last=Filler | first=Martin | journal=[[Architectural Record]] | date=November 2005 | url=http://archrecord.construction.com/resources/magindex/0511.asp | publisher=[[McGraw Hill]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite book| title=New Museums | publisher=[[Telleri]] | year=1999 | isbn=2-7450-0036-5 | last=Donzel | first=Catherine }}</ref>
A challenge for museum architecture is the differing purposes of the building.{{citation needed|date=February 2013}} The museum collection must be preserved, but it also needs to be made accessible to the public. Climate control may be very important for the objects in the collection.
==History== An early example of architecture for a purpose-built museum is the [[Museum of the History of Science]] building in [[Oxford]], [[England]], originally built to house the [[Ashmolean Museum]].
In the 20th century, museums have been combined with war memorials to serve multiple purposes. The [[Australian War Memorial]] in [[Canberra]], for example, is a place of commemoration as well as for collection and display. It contains a museum, an archive and a shrine. It was designed by [[Emil Sodersten]] and [[John Crust]] in a contemporary [[Neoclassical architecture|neoclassical]] style reminiscent of [[Edwin Lutyens|Lutyens]] with detailing influenced by [[Art Deco]].
The [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum]] in New York City, USA (opened in 1959), by [[Frank Lloyd Wright]] is an important architectural landmark and icon of the 20th century. Another classic 20th century example of iconic museum architecture is the titanium-covered [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao]] in Spain by [[Frank Gehry]] (opened in 1997). Gehry has undertaken many major museum architecture projects, including the [[Experience Music Project]] in Seattle, USA, the [[Weisman Art Museum]] in Minneapolis, USA, the [[Vitra Design Museum]] and [[MARTa Museum]] in Germany, and the [[Art Gallery of Ontario]] in Toronto, Canada.
Successful examples of modern architecture being married with existing museum buildings include the [[Louvre Pyramid]] by [[I. M. Pei]] in Paris, France (1989), and more recently the [[Queen Elizabeth II Great Court]] by [[Norman Foster]] at the [[British Museum]], London, England (2000).
[[David Chipperfield]] designed many notable museums, including the award-winning [[River and Rowing Museum]] in Henley-on-Thames, England, in 1997.<ref>{{cite journal | url=http://www.architectural-review.com/home/ar-archive/ar-1997-january-david-chipperfields-river-and-rowing-museum/8611738.article | title=AR 1997 January — David Chipperfield's River and Rowing Museum | last=Richards | first=Ivor | journal=[[The Architectural Review]] | date=23 February 2011}}</ref> This won in 1999 the [[RIBA]] ''Architecture in Arts and Leisure Award'' and the [[Royal Fine Art Commission]] Trust/[[British Sky Broadcasting]] ''Best Building Award (England)''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.wakefield.gov.uk/NR/rdonlyres/74906CDF-4437-45C1-8470-4208CCD7901B/0/David_Chipperfield_CV.pdf | title=David Chipperfield | website=www.wakefield.gov.uk | publisher=[[Wakefield Council]] | location=UK | accessdate=October 14, 2011 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Chipperfield also designed the [[Figge Art Museum]] in Davenport, Iowa, USA (2005), the [[Museum of Modern Literature]] in Marbach, Germany (2006), and the reconstructed [[Neues Museum]] in Berlin, Germany (2009).
Museum architecture sometimes involves the [[Adaptive reuse|conversion]] of old buildings that have outlived their usefulness but that are still of historic interest. A notable example is the [[Dalí Theatre and Museum]] or the conversion of the [[Bankside Power Station]] designed by Sir [[Giles Gilbert Scott]] into the [[Tate Modern]] in 2000, based on design by [[Herzog & de Meuron]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.carillionplc.com/sectors/sectors_leisure_tate.asp | title=Tate Modern | publisher=[[Carillion]] PLC | accessdate=October 14, 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928130817/http://www.carillionplc.com/sectors/sectors_leisure_tate.asp | archivedate=September 28, 2011 | df= }}</ref> Information about the conversion was the basis for a 2008 documentary ''Architects Herzog and de Meuron: Alchemy of Building & Tate Modern''.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=2483168510674278477 | title=Architects Herzog and de Meuron: Alchemy of Building & Tate Modern | publisher=[[Google Video]] | year=2008 | accessdate=October 14, 2011}}</ref>
[[Finegold Alexander + Associates Inc]], an architecture firm based in Boston, Massachusetts, USA, established in 1962, has undertaken museum architecture projects including [[Ellis Island|Ellis Island National Monument and Museum]]<ref>[http://www.nps.gov/archive/stli/serv02.htm STLI Service 2 Description], [[National Park Service]], USA.</ref> (Associated Architects with Beyer Blinder Belle Architects) and the [[United States Holocaust Memorial Museum]] (Associated Architects with Pei Cobb Freed & Partners).
==Architects== As well as the architects mentioned above, other architects notable for their contributions to museum architecture include:
* [[Philip Freelon]] ([[Smithsonian]] [[National Museum of African American History and Culture]], 2003, USA; the [[Museum of the African Diaspora]], 2005, USA) * [[Leonard Jacobson]] ([[East Building]] of the [[National Gallery of Art]], [[Washington, D.C.]], 1978, USA; West Wing of the [[Museum of Fine Arts, Boston|Museum of Fine Arts]], [[Boston, Massachusetts]], 1981, USA; [[Portland Museum of Art]], [[Portland, Maine]], 1982, USA; the [[Louvre]], 1980s/90s, Paris, France) * [[Kengo Kuma]] ([[Kitakami Canal Museum]], [[Tokyo]], 1994, Japan; [[Suntory Museum of Art]], 2007, Japan; [[V&A at Dundee]],<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.thecourier.co.uk/News/Dundee/article/12285/v-and-a-museum-architect-kengo-kuma-to-give-dundee-lecture.html | title=V&A museum architect Kengo Kuma to give Dundee lecture | work=[[The Courier (Dundee)|The Courier]] | location=[[Dundee]], [[Scotland]] | date=28 March 2011 | accessdate=October 30, 2011 | first=Stefan | last=Morkis | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111214022938/http://www.thecourier.co.uk/News/Dundee/article/12285/v-and-a-museum-architect-kengo-kuma-to-give-dundee-lecture.html | archivedate=14 December 2011 | df= }}</ref> [[Dundee]], 2010, [[Scotland]]) * [[Akira Kuryu]] ([[Uemura Naomi Memorial Museum]], 1994, Japan; [[Okazaki Mindscape Museum]], 1996, Japan) * [[Daniel Libeskind]] ([[Jewish Museum, Berlin]] 1989-1999, [[Imperial War Museum North]] 1997-2001, [[Royal Ontario Museum]] (extension), 2002-2007) * [[SANAA]] * [[Katayama Tōkuma]] ([[Nara National Museum]], 1894, Japan; Kyoto Imperial Museum, 1895, now the [[Kyoto National Museum]], Japan) * [[Stanton Williams]] ([[Grand Musée d'Art]],<ref>[http://www.e-architect.co.uk/architects/stanton_williams.htm Stanton Williams Architects], [http://www.e-architect.co.uk/ e-architect], UK.</ref> 2011, [[Nantes]], France)
==Gallery== <gallery> File:The National War Memorial, Canberra.JPG|The [[Australian War Memorial]], Canberra, including a national military museum, completed 1941, designed by [[Emil Sodersten]] and [[John Crust]] File:Louvre at night centered.jpg|The [[Louvre Pyramid]] at the [[Louvre]] in Paris (1989) File:Guggenheim-bilbao-jan05.jpg|The [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao]], designed by [[Frank Gehry]] and opened in 1997 File:River-Rowing-Museum-Henley.jpg|The [[River and Rowing Museum]] in Henley-on-Thames, designed by [[David Chipperfield]] and opened in 1997 File:Tate Modern viewed from Thames Pleasure Boat - geograph.org.uk - 307445.jpg|The [[Tate Modern]] in London, converted by [[Herzog & de Meuron]] in 2000 File:British Museum Great Court, London, UK - Diliff.jpg|The [[Queen Elizabeth II Great Court|Great Court]] at the [[British Museum]], London (2000) File:Centro de Ciência de Macau.jpg|The [[Macao Science Center]] in [[Macau]], designed by [[Pei Partnership Architects]] in association with [[I. M. Pei]] (2009) </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Music librarianship''' is the area of [[librarianship]] that pertains to music collections and their development, [[cataloging]], [[Preservation (library and archival science)|preservation]] and maintenance, as well as [[Reference#Libraries|reference]] issues connected with musical works and music literature. Music librarians usually have degrees in both music and librarianship (typically, a [[Master of Library and Information Science]] and at least a college-level music degree). Music librarians deal with standard librarianship duties such as cataloging and reference, but the addition of [[Sheet music|music score]]s and recordings to collections complicates these tasks. Therefore, music librarians generally read music and have at least a basic understanding of both [[music theory]] and [[music history]] to aid in their duties.
==History==
Most early written [[classical music]] was predominantly sacred; collections of written music and literature were held by monasteries, cathedrals, and other religious establishments, such as church music societies, offices, and seminaries. As universities emerged in the 12th century, libraries formed throughout Europe, and obtained donations or gifts from monasteries and private collectors. The advent of [[National library|national and centralized libraries]] two centuries later allowed for greater attention to special materials like music collections. Up to the end of the 15th century, music collections had been limited to religious organizations, private collectors, or small areas of university libraries. Public collections grew with the development of printing at the end of the 15th century and the surge of scholarly and artistic endeavors of the [[Renaissance]].<ref>Benton, Rita. Libraries §2 Early History. Grove Music.</ref>
Music librarianship since the Renaissance has grown alongside modern librarianship, but with more unique, dedicated facilities for materials. In the 18th and 19th centuries, the establishment of [[College or university school of music|conservatories]] created a need for music collections that supported learning at those institutions. While the proliferation of [[Library classification|classification]] schemes has given music a niche in modern public and academic collections, other institutions maintaining music-only collections have contributed to the rise of music libraries. These include conservatories, music information centers, composers' and performing rights associations, opera houses, music publishers, and media facilities involved with broadcasting and film.<ref>Benton, Rita. Libraries §3 Types. Grove Music.</ref>
==Education==
In the United States, most librarianship degrees begin at the graduate level. At the undergraduate level, potential music librarians study music at any number of schools and programs (theory, history, performance, production, business and education). Following the coupling of an MLS and undergraduate music degree, many music librarians also elect to study music at the graduate level. Additionally, doctorate programs are available in both music and library science. In Masters level degrees of library science, typical music-oriented offerings examine the different materials of music collections, such as music-specific dictionaries, encyclopedias, bibliographies, indexes, and other music literature. Music librarianship offerings may also address music reference, cataloging issues, [[Library collection development|collection development]] and maintenance, [[Bookbinding|binding]] and repair, preservation, evaluation methods of antiquarian material appraisal, and music librarianship education (teaching methods). Certain music librarianship areas of practice do not require a library degree- performance library management, for example.<ref>MLA. "Music Librarianship- Is it for you?" Music Library Association- MLA Employment and Education. http://www.musiclibraryassoc.org/employmentanded/musiclibrarianship.shtml</ref>
In 1974, Music Library Association published a set of qualifications for music librarians. The “minimum qualifications expected of a beginning music librarian” were restricted to knowledge of materials and resources of the music library, general librarianship skills, and general music knowledge which states that candidates for music librarian positions should have music degrees preferably a bachelor’s and a master's degree; a master’s in library science; courses in music librarianship and/or experience working in a music library; familiarity with foreign languages, and a commitment to continued growth and education as seen through work in professional organizations, such as the Music Library Association.<ref>Oates, J. (2004). Music Librarianship Education: Problems and Solutions. Music Reference Servis Quarterly, pp. 1-24.</ref>
Librarians usually receive on-the-job training to become familiar with the inner workings of their collections. This may include training in a particular classification scheme (such as [[Library of Congress Classification]] or ANSCR), binding procedures, or protocols regarding patron usage of materials. Additionally, many librarians elect to participate in continuing education classes and programs available through professional organizations and other outlets. For example, music librarians preparing for a large scale cataloging project might take a cataloging workshop focusing on a particular scheme or music cataloging issue. Librarians training for a position that involves a new technology might apply to classes offered by external companies in specific software or hardware.
The ultimate goal of music library education is to engender core competencies in students preparing to enter the field.<ref>“Core Competencies and Music Librarians” Music Library Association, 2002. http://www.musiclibraryassoc.org/pdf/Core_Competencies.pdf</ref>
The Music Library Association maintains a list of library and information science schools that teach music librarianship or accept music credits as part of their library degree programs. Note: this list is current as of November 2011. [http://www.musiclibraryassoc.org/employment.aspx?id=77 "Directory of Library School Offerings in Music Librarianship"]
==Facilities==
''See [[Music library]]''
Music librarians work with collections in a variety of settings. Music libraries take several forms, and often are maintained as a part of a larger collection or institution. The nature of a music library facility depends heavily on the role of the music library within its parent institution. At academic institutions dedicated to music (such as a music conservatory), the music library may be the main library collection of the school. In colleges or universities where music is only one aspect of academic focus, the music collection may be integrated into the greater library system, or a separate collection from the main library.<ref>Jones, Malcolm. Music Librarianship. London: Clive Bingley, 1979. 15-16.</ref> Performance music libraries serve a unique function and are often housed with performance spaces. Entirely digital music collections require server space and proper housing of digitization equipment, although many music libraries in the process of digitization have facilities for such services. Other factors influencing facilities include the types of materials in the collection, the users who will access those materials, and budget constraints related to implementation, acquisition, maintenance, and service.
==Areas of Practice==
Most music librarians have an array of tasks to perform, depending on the nature of their collection and position. General duties include cataloging and reference, acquisition and collection development. It is common to specialize in one or more areas of music librarianship, particularly for work in special collections.
===Cataloging and Classification===
Music materials require different cataloging methods than other fields. While music literature can be classified and cataloged following general cataloging rules that apply to all subjects, music scores and sound recordings present unique challenges of both description and access.<ref>Redfern, Brian. Organizing Music in Libraries. Vol. 2: Cataloging. London: Clive Bingley, Ltd., 1979. 17.</ref> Examples include uniform titles, responsibility (composer versus performer), and how to classify sound recordings (by genre, composer, etc.).<ref>Smiraglia, Richard. Bibliographic Control of Music, 1897-2000. MLA Index and Bibliography Series No. 32. Lanham, MD: Scarecrow Press, 2006. 6-8.</ref>
===References===
Music reference requires knowledge of music history, the ability to read music and have at least a basic understanding of music theory, and a strong grasp of music reference literature: dictionaries and encyclopedias, indexes and directories, bibliographies and discographies, and music score formats.<ref>Jones, Malcolm. Music Librarianship. London: Clive Bingley, 1979. 74-78.</ref> Reference also necessitates adeptness with electronic resources and tools. Reading ability in German and Romance languages are practical skills to possess when working closely with western classical music. When working with non-western music, an ethnomusicology background may be essential.<ref>MLA. "Music Librarianship- Is it for you?" Music Library Association- MLA Employment and Education. http://www.musiclibraryassoc.org/employmentanded/musiclibrarianship.shtml</ref>
===Acquisition and Collection Development===
In order to grow their collections, music librarians purchase books and music reference materials, subscribe to serials, order music scores and sound recordings, and buy or license electronic resources. This involves not only contact with publishers and other agencies that provide music materials, but also budgetary management of library funds.
===Preservation==
Preservation of music is the maintenance of musical compositions and preventing music from extinction. Music collections require certain conditions for the preservation of printed materials. Appropriate air regulation prevents the accumulation of moisture, and materials should be protected from the possibility of water or fire damage. Music scores often need new binding either because of weak publisher bindings or due to age. Although binding is done mainly for preservation, it also to provide uniformity (binding music allows for uniform barcode or call number placement, for example). Music library staff usually allocate part of their duties to managing binding and processing of scores. Some music libraries outsource binding to professional companies, and a few music libraries have dedicated binding staff and resources.<ref>Knowing the Score: Preserving collections of music. Comp. Mark Roosa and Jane Gottlieb. MLA Technical Reports No. 23. Metuchen, NJ: Scarecrow Press, Inc., 1994. 8-11.</ref>
Sound recordings present another level of preservation. Light protection, temperature and humidity control, and particular shelving, packaging, and cleaning procedures must be followed for proper storage for preserving physical materials.<ref>“Cylinder, Disc and Tape Care in a Nutshell (Preservation, Library of Congress).” Library of Congress. https://www.loc.gov/preserv/care/record.html</ref> Electronic files (documents and sound recordings) require preservation, too. Migration, replication, emulation, and metadata attachment aid in preservation of [[electronic document|digital documents]].<ref>Rothenberg, J. "Ensuring the Longevity of Digital Documents." Scientific American 272, 1 (1995). http://www.clir.org/pubs/archives/ensuring.pdf</ref>
''See [[Digital Preservation]]''
===Special Collections===
'''Performance'''
Performance music librarians act as support for performing groups by acquiring printed music and preparing it for performance. Preparation involves managing multiple parts, collating and creating folders of music for each player, and usually marking specific notes or edits in the music, such as bowing directions for string instruments. Performance libraries then store the music for future performance or return it (if the music has been rented).
'''Production'''
''See [[Production music|Production Music]]''
Production music librarians maintain collections that own licensed music. This music is distributed on license to other institutions or performing groups for profit.
'''Antiquarian and Rare Collections'''
Antiquarian music collections are usually housed in very large music libraries, institutional special collections archives, or in private collections. The antiquarian trade often involves purchasing materials from private collections at auctions. Antiquarian and rare materials require extra care in handling and preservation. The age of materials can reach back several hundred years and can have considerable value.
'''Digital Collections'''
''See [[Digital library]]''
[[Digitization]] is the process by which printed music or literature is converted to digital formats by a scanner. Digitization is also the process of transferring audio formats (for example, converting music on an LP record to mp3). Materials may also be born-digital; that is, created originally as a digital document or file. Many music librarians dedicate part of their duties to digitizing elements of their collection. Some libraries are entirely digital collections, and may not have physical access at all. These are usually hosted on the Internet or a network, and most often electronic access is limited to specific user groups (sometimes by subscription). Digital libraries deal with digital decay, security and access, and copyright issues involved with distributing and/or copying data to users.
==Technology==
Because of the nature of the materials in a music library, music librarians employ technologies related to audio delivery, access to digital material, and print music preservation and presentation.
Audio collections require dependable audio-delivery systems, including headphones, receivers, and audio players (CD, DAT, phonograph, etc.). Attention is paid in particular to where listening stations are located in the library, to accommodate for noise, access to audio materials, and access to other technology like computers (especially if audio is streamed through a computer from an online digital collection). Some libraries may opt for listening stations or rooms separate from the main library area.
Music libraries that digitize parts of their collection require scanners for printed materials, and devices for transferring analog audio to digital formats. Computers are needed to control, convert, stream, store, preserve, or otherwise manipulate digitized material. Entirely digital collections involve technology for connecting users to electronic materials, usually hosted on the Internet. Information professionals involved with these projects deal with issues such as streaming, security and access, copy protection and copyright, and database management.
==Professional Organizations==
Professional organizations related to music librarianship include:
* The [[Music Library Association]] (MLA): the official organization for the music librarianship profession [http://musiclibraryassoc.org link] * [http://www.iaml.info/ International Association of Music Libraries, Archives and Documentation Centres] [[International Association of Music Libraries, Archives and Documentation Centres|(IAML)]]: a group with a wide scope, sustaining the development of music library projects around the world. * [http://www.mola-inc.org/ Major Orchestra Librarians' Association] (MOLA): Generally dedicated to performance music library issues, MOLA membership is open to conductors, musicians, and publishers, as well as performance music librarians. * [http://www.ala.org/ala/acrl/aboutacrl/acrlsections/arts/arts.cfm Association of College and Research Libraries, Arts Section] (ACRL ARTS): [[Association of College and Research Libraries]]ACRL ARTS is a division of the [[American Library Association]] (ALA), the main professional organization for librarians in the United States. This division focuses on both visual and performing arts, and is like a smaller version of the Music Library Association. * [http://olacinc.org/drupal/ Online Audiovisual Catalogers] [[Online Audiovisual Catalogers, Inc.|(OLAC)]]: a support website for cataloging issues related to AV materials, aiding in communication between catalogers as a means to develop uniform cataloging practices. * [http://www.tla-online.org/ Theatre Library Association] (TLA): The TLA is a support organization for librarians involved with performing arts collections, including dance, motion picture, and broadcasting. * [http://www.musicoclcusers.org/ Music OCLC Users Group] (MOUG): The Music Online Computer Library Center Users Group is a resource for music librarians who use OCLC services. * [http://www.ams-net.org/ American Musicological Society] [[American Musicological Society|(AMS)]]: The organization dedicated to research in different fields of music. * [http://www.arsc-audio.org/ Association for Recorded Sound Collections] [[Association for Recorded Sound Collections|(ARSC)]]: supports all types of audio collections and professions related to sound recordings. ARSC is geared particularly toward preservation and projects studying sound recordings and collections. * [http://www.american-music.org/ Society for American Music] [[Society for American Music|(SAM)]]: The organization concerned with all aspects of North and Central American (and Caribbean) music.
Additionally, music librarians will find support from academic and corporate institutions that offer grants, continuing education, inter-institutional cooperation (such as interlibrary loan or out-sourced services like digitization), and resources aiding in the completion of tasks in the field.
==Current Issues==
Cataloging concerns remain constant topics for debate in music librarianship. Digitization problems and electronic bibliographic, reference and archival tools are also at the front lines of the field as library technology moves forward. Efficiency of digitization has been increasing as library storage space has been diminishing, so more libraries are turning toward digitization not only to preserve materials in electronic formats, but also to save space. The open access movement is having an effect on music libraries, notably in subscription- or fee-based electronic services versus freely accessible electronic services.
Copyright is another major issue in this field. As a score travels from the pen of a composer to the music stand of a performer, it changes many hands. Composers may copyright and even distribute their own work, but it might also be distributed by a corporate publisher. Music libraries pay for copies of works, but sometimes only rent the work through a license. Because music copyright is an intricate issue, music librarians must carefully abide by copyright guidelines, such as those noted on the Music Library Association website.
Major field publications such as ''Notes'' (the MLA's quarterly journal), as well as email listservs, forums, and presentations at meetings of professional organizations, highlight and analyze key trends in music librarianship.
==See also==
* [[Music Library Association]] * [[Music library]] * [[Production music]]
==Notes==
{{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://musiclibraryassoc.org Music Library Association] * [http://www.iaml.info IAML - International Association of Music Libraries, Archives and Documentation Centres] * [http://copyright.musiclibraryassoc.org/ Copyright For Music Librarians] via the Music Library Association

'''Reference'''
