{{Infobox film | name = Norma Rae | image = Norma_rae_ver2.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | image_size = | director = [[Martin Ritt]] | producer = [[Tamara Asseyev]]
Alex Rose | writer = [[Harriet Frank Jr.]]
[[Irving Ravetch]] | starring = [[Sally Field]]
[[Beau Bridges]]
[[Ron Leibman]] | music = [[David Shire]] | cinematography = [[John A. Alonzo]] | editing = Sidney Levin | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = {{Film date|1979|03|02|ref1=}} | runtime = 110 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $4.5 millionAubrey Solomon, ''Twentieth Century Fox: A Corporate and Financial History'', Scarecrow Press, 1989 p259 | gross = $22 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=normarae.htm|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|title=Norma Rae, Box Office Information|accessdate=June 6, 2013}} }} '''''Norma Rae''''' is a 1979 American [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] directed by [[Martin Ritt]] from a screenplay written by [[Harriet Frank Jr.]] and [[Irving Ravetch]]. Based on the true story of [[Crystal Lee Sutton]],Obituary [[New York Times]], September 15, 2009.Obituary [[Los Angeles Times]], September 20, 2009. which was told in the 1975 book ''Crystal Lee, a Woman of Inheritance'' by ''[[New York Times]]'' reporter Henry P. Leifermann,''Crystal Lee, a Woman of Inheritance'', Henry P. Leifermann, Macmillan (1975), {{ISBN|0-02-570220-3}} the film stars [[Sally Field]] in the titular role. [[Beau Bridges]], [[Ron Leibman]], [[Pat Hingle]], [[Barbara Baxley]] and [[Gail Strickland]] are featured in supporting roles. The film's narrative follows Norma Rae, a factory worker from a small town in [[North Carolina]] who becomes involved in the [[trade union|labor union]] activities at the [[textile]] factory where she works after the health of her and her co-workers is compromised.{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/1896/year/1979.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Norma Rae |accessdate=2009-05-24|work=festival-cannes.com}} ''Norma Rae'' premiered at the [[1979 Cannes Film Festival|32nd Cannes Film Festival]] where it competed for the [[Palme d'Or]], while Field received the [[Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Prix d'interprétation féminine]]. The film was released theatrically on March 2, 1979, and upon its release was a critical and commercial success with critics appreciating the film's direction, screenplay, message and performances (in particular of Field's), while the film grossed $22 million on a production budget of $4.5 million. It received six [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] nominations at the [[52nd Academy Awards]] including for [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], and won two: [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] (Field) and [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]] for its theme song, "[[It Goes Like It Goes]]."See film's entry at IMDb.com. The film was selected for preservation at the [[National Film Registry]] of the [[Library of Congress]] in 2011, deemed as being "culturally, aesthetically or historically significant". == Plot == Norma Rae Wilson is a worker in a cotton mill that has taken too much of a toll on the health of her family for her to ignore their poor working conditions. She is also a single mother with two children by different fathers, one dead and the other negligent, and frequently has flings with other men to alleviate her loneliness and boredom. Initially, management tries to divert her frequent protests by promoting her to "spot checker," where she is responsible for making sure other workers are fulfilling work quotas. She reluctantly takes the job for the pay hike, but when fellow employees, including her own father, shun her for effectively being a "fink" to the bosses, she demands to be fired. Instead, she is demoted back to the line. Two men enter her life that change her perspective. A former co-worker, Sonny Webster, asks her out after earlier causing trouble for her at the mill. Divorced with a daughter, he proposes marriage after a short courtship; recognizing how long it has been since she met a non-selfish man to keep company with, she accepts his offer. And after a few charged encounters with a New York [[union organizer]], Reuben Warshowsky, Norma Rae listens to him deliver a speech that spurs her to join the effort to unionize her shop. This causes conflict at home when Sonny observes she's not spending enough time in the home and is frequently exhausted when she is present. When her father drops dead at the mill, a death that could have been averted had he been allowed to leave his post early instead of wait for his allotted break, she is more determined to continue the fight. Management retaliates against the organization efforts, first by rearranging shifts so that workers are doing more work at less pay, and then by posting fliers with racial invective in the hope of dividing white and black workers and diluting the momentum. Warshowsky demands she copy down the racist flier word for word in order to use it as evidence for government sanctions against her mill. When she attempts to transcribe the flier, management attempts to stop her, then fire her on grounds of creating a disturbance, and call the police to remove her from the plant. While awaiting the sheriff, Norma Rae takes a piece of cardboard, writes the word "UNION" on it, stands on her work table, and slowly turns to show the sign around the room. One by one, the other workers stop their mill machines, and eventually, the entire room becomes silent. After all the machines have been switched off, Norma Rae is taken to jail but is freed by Reuben. Upon returning home to her family, Norma decides to talk to her children and tell them the story of her life, their questionable parentage, and recent arrest, so that they are prepared for any smears that may come from those hoping to discredit her efforts. After a tense exchange with Reuben, Sonny asks her if they have been intimate; she says no, but acknowledges "he's in my head." Sonny, in turn, tells her there's no other woman in his head and he will always remain with her. An election to [[labor union|unionize]] the factory takes place, with Norma and Reuben listening as best as possible from outside the mill as reporters and TV cameras observe the vote count. With a difference shy of 100 votes, the result is a victory for the union. Shortly after, Reuben says goodbye to Norma; despite his being smitten with her throughout the movie, they only shake hands because he knows she is married and loves her husband, and Reuben heads back to New York. == Inspiration == The story is based on [[Crystal Lee Sutton]]'s life as a textile worker in [[Roanoke Rapids, North Carolina]], where the battle for the workers' union took place against a [[WestPoint Home|J.P. Stevens Textiles]] mill. Her actual protest in the mill is the scene in the film where she writes the sign "UNION" and stands on her worktable until all machines are silent. Although Sutton was fired from her job, the mill was unionized, and she later went to work as an organizer for the textile union.Eric Leif Davin, "Crystal Lee," ''In These Times'', March 5–18, 1980, pp. 16-17. == Cast == {{div col|colwidth=17em}} * [[Sally Field]] as Norma Rae Webster * [[Beau Bridges]] as Sonny Webster * [[Ron Leibman]] as Reuben Warshowsky * [[Pat Hingle]] as Vernon * [[Barbara Baxley]] as Leona * [[Gail Strickland]] as Bonnie Mae * [[Morgan Paull]] as Wayne Billings * John Calvin as Ellis Harper * [[Noble Willingham]] as Leroy Mason * [[Grace Zabriskie]] as Linette Odum * [[Robert Broyles]] as Sam Bolen {{div col end}} == Production notes == ''Norma Rae'' was filmed on location in [[Opelika, Alabama]]. The mill scenes were shot at the Opelika Manufacturing Corp., and the motel scenes were filmed at The Golden Cherry Motel.{{cite web|url=http://www.thetuskegeenews.com/articles/2009/04/23/opinion/doc49ef76ed90cef476568380.txt|title=When Norma Rae came to town|last=Rhodes|first=Guy|date=April 23, 2009|publisher=thetuskegeenews.com|accessdate=June 2, 2013}} == Awards and honors == The film ''Norma Rae'' won [[Academy Awards]] for [[Academy Award for Best Actress|Best Actress in a Leading Role]] (Sally Field) and [[Academy Award for Best Original Song|Best Original Song]] ([[David Shire]] and [[Norman Gimbel]] for "[[It Goes Like It Goes]]"). It was also nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]] and for [[Academy Award for Writing Adapted Screenplay|Best Writing, Screenplay Based on Material from Another Medium]]. The film was also nominated to the [[Palme d'Or]] (Golden Palm) at the [[1979 Cannes Film Festival]] and Field was awarded [[Prix d'interprétation féminine|Best Actress]], in Cannes, for her performance. In 2011, ''Norma Rae'' was selected for the United States [[National Film Registry]] by the [[Library of Congress]] as being "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant".{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2011/11-240.html|title=2011 National Film Registry More Than a Box of Chocolates|work=Library of Congress|date=December 28, 2011|accessdate=December 29, 2011}} The film is recognized by [[American Film Institute]] in these lists: * 2003: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Heroes & Villains]]: ** Norma Rae Webster – #15 Hero{{cite web|last= |first= |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Heroes & Villains |url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/handv100.pdf |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |date= |accessdate=2016-08-14}} * 2004: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Songs]]: ** "[[It Goes Like It Goes]]" – Nominated{{cite web|url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/songs400.pdf |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Songs Nominees |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2016-08-14}} * 2006: [[AFI's 100 Years...100 Cheers]] – #16{{cite web|last= |first= |title=AFI's 100 Years...100 Cheers |url=http://www.afi.com/Docs/100Years/cheers100.pdf |publisher=[[American Film Institute]] |date= |accessdate=2016-08-14}} ==Home media releases== ''Norma Rae'' was released on [[VHS]] in December 1996, on [[DVD]] in December 2006, and [[Blu-ray]] in April 2014. ==Musical Adaptation== In December 2017, it was announced that ''Norma Rae'' is being adapted into a stage musical. [[Rosanne Cash]] is set to compose the score.https://www.broadway.com/buzz/190654/rosanne-cash-is-writing-a-norma-rae-musical/ == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0079638|Norma Rae}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|norma_rae|Norma Rae}} * {{tcmdb title|85210|Norma Rae}} * {{amg title|35621|Norma Rae}} * {{mojo title|normarae|Norma Rae}} * [http://www.ncnn.com/ ''North Carolina News Network''] news story, [http://www.ncnn.com/content/view/4931/26/ Inspiration for ''Norma Rae'' Dies] {{Martin Ritt}} [[Category:1979 films]] [[Category:1970s drama films]] [[Category:20th Century Fox films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:Cotton production]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Feminist films]] [[Category:Films about activists]] [[Category:Films about the labor movement]] [[Category:Films directed by Martin Ritt]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films featuring a Best Actress Academy Award-winning performance]] [[Category:Films featuring a Best Drama Actress Golden Globe-winning performance]] [[Category:Films set in 1978]] [[Category:Films shot in Alabama]] [[Category:Films that won the Best Original Song Academy Award]] [[Category:United States National Film Registry films]] [[Category:UNITE HERE]] [[Category:Media portrayals of the working class]]

{{refimprove|date=April 2009}}
{{Infobox record label | name = Phunk Studio | image = [[File:phunkstudio.jpg]] | image_bg = | parent = | founded = 1994 | founder = Alvin Tan, Melvin Chee, Jackson Tan, William Chan | genre = | country = Singapore | url = www.phunkstudio.com }} '''PHUNK''' is a [[Singapore]]-based [[contemporary art]] and [[design]] collective. PHUNK was founded in 1994 by four esteemed [[Singapore]]an artists/designers of various art practices: Alvin Tan, Melvin Chee, Jackson Tan, and William Chan, who met as fellow design students at [[LASALLE College of the Arts]].[http://www.computerarts.co.uk/in_depth/interviews/phunk Computer Arts Magazine Interview]
== Style == Unlike other contemporary collectives or artists, PHUNK prides itself in blurring the lines between creative processes in their works of fine art and commercial design. Strongly believing in not differentiating between art and design, PHUNK explores, expresses and communicates its ideas through different mediums. With their multitude of projects, exhibitions, and collaborations spanning across art, design, publishing, fashion, music, film and interactive art pieces, they more often than not also intentionally blur the lines and challenge conventional boundaries that separate art and design, creativity and commerce, craft and technology, east and west, fantasy and reality, control and chaos, love and hate, friendship and partnership, and audio and visual works. PHUNK designs and artworks always been greatly influenced by popular culture. The artists believe that popular culture influences and informs consumers daily and has its own unique and comprehensive visual language and iconography. Utilising popular culture's ever-evolving series of metaphors, codes, symbols and icons that are widely recognised and embraced by the masses, PHUNK prides itself in experimenting with contexts and visual symbols in their works to create a unique visual language and system. PHUNK's main access of inspiration and outlet of work is through visuals, information and cultural influences within our their collective interests and backgrounds. As kids, the artists started out as avid collectors and junkies of popular culture paraphernalia, the influences of which have since been a recurring theme in their work. Always returning to and remembering their roots, the artists were born in the '70s, the golden era of television, movies and pop culture. Even in their current works, allusions to influences kids, they grew up having grown up watching plenty of film and television, including popular Hong Kong kung fu movies, Cantonese TV series, Japanese cartoon animes, and American TV programmes. It was also the beginning of the Hollywood blockbuster era. They also read a lot of comic books ranging from Japanese manga, and American Superhero comics from DC and Marvel. As teenagers in the '80s, they were fascinated by British indie pop and new wave music, as well as American rock music and MTV. Upon entering art college in the '90s, they were heavily influenced by various art and design movements such as the Bauhaus, Fluxus, Situationism, Pop Art, Swiss Modernist and Postmodernist design. Nowadays, they are influenced and informed by travels to different parts of the world and meeting fellow creatives who share their interests and love for everything pop culture.
== History == PHUNK was founded in 1994 but first and foremost born of friendship and common loves. Alvin, Melvin, Jackson, and William met as fellow design students studying Visual Communications at [[LASALLE College of the Arts]] in Singapore. In 1995 to 1997, the artists served their time doing [[National service in Singapore|National Service]]. The four served the mandatory two years as full-time Military Policemen under the [[Singapore Armed Forces]]. It was also during these years that they found time to experiment, jam, and create visual works in Jack's home over the weekends. Having realised they shared many common interests, ranging from old Hong Kong kungfu TV serials, Chinese mythology and Japanese manga, to British indie music, American pop culture, pretty girls, alcohol, and parties, the group started out trying to start a band. Their musical ventures were discontinued shortly after, but soon other modes of artistic expressions were born. The artists then proceeded to create visuals and graphics on the iMac in Jackson’s bedroom and sent these graphics out to friends and family. It was in these years too that they founded 'Guerilla Fonts' to create original digital typeface designs. These typeface designs were then sent to David Carson's [http://www.garagefonts.com/ Garage Fonts], Del Mar, California. Shortly after, in 1998 Garage Fonts officially distributed Guerilla Fonts' original typeface designs worldwide. PHUNK was then invited to write the introduction for the book, 'New Typographics 2', published by Japanese publishers, PIE books. Thereafter, the artists founded and launched 'Trigger' Magazine, of which 20,000 copies snapped out within a week. PHUNK also begun organising themed parties with Zouk, and the launch of ‘Trigger’ was cited as one of the top 10 Zouk parties of all time. PHUNK started long-standing working relationship with MTV Asia in 1999, and many of their works went on to win awards in various award shows. In the design sphere, PHUNK also created Phiz dingbats, marking the start of the collective's unique illustration style. 2000 marked the start of a series of milestones for PHUNK. PHUNK has bagged numerous design awards and recognitions both locally and internationally such as: Finalist, Macromedia International Type Design (1998), Finalist, Apple Design Competition (1998), Selected, American Center of Design - The 100 Show (2000), Finalist, D&AD (2001), Finalist, One Show (2001), Finalist, Creative Circle Awards (2002), Merit, Singapore Design Awards (2002), Best of Show, Singapore Design Awards (2004), Best Visual Arts & Best Of Show, Singapore StreetStyle Awards (2005). PHUNK has repeatedly been awarded by PROMAX ASIA, emerging with Gold and Silver medals in 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005 and 2006. PHUNK was also awarded the ‘Designer of the Year’ at the President’s Design Awards 2017 in Singapore, making history as the youngest ever recipient of the award, the highest Singapore design accolade that can be attained. 2011 marked a new era for the collective after a disastrous fire occurred during the moving of PHUNK's studio from Lasalle to Tanjong Katong destroyed everything in the studio. Initially identified as ':phunk', or 'Phunk Studio', the collective then officially changed its name to what we now still know as 'PHUNK'. The collective subsequently went on to participate in various art shows locally, regionally, and internationally, as well as make their mark in the international design community through various collaborations and art shows.
== Artworks == PHUNK's body of work includes visual art and design pieces as well as installations. It involves the use of various mediums ranging from silkscreen prints, mixed media pieces and sculptures to the use of acrylic, wood, and vinyl figurines. * Army of Love * Control Chaos * Control Chaos Giant * Cosmic Triptych * DayDreamer Triptych II * D.I.S.C.O. (Dreams in Social Cosmic Odyssey) * Electricity Neon * Eccentricity * From The Bottom Of My Pencil Case * Fuck Art * Heavenly Boy On Wheels * Hello * Hope, Kiss, Live, Rock * Lao Fu Zhi * Lei Gong * ART! (Slippery When Wet, Crush & Buru) * L.O.V.E (Summer) * Love Bomb * Love Supreme * New Dreams Of An Old World * New World Triptych I * Pseudo Human Being * Queer * The King Of Dreams * Universality I * Universality II * When The Saints Go Marching In
== Collaborations == PHUNK has worked with brands such as [[Nike Inc.|Nike]], [[Nokia]], [[MTV]], [[Daimler Chrysler]], [[Comme des Garçons]], [[Levi Strauss & Co.|Levi's]], and [[Tiger Beer]]. One of their artworks, ''Electricity'', was cited in the book ''Graphic Design, A New History''[http://www.designobserver.com/archives/entry.html?id=30274 Graphic Design, A New History] as "Instances of truly global graphic design." They were awarded "Designer of the Year" in 2007 at the Singapore President's Design Award,[http://www.designsingapore.org/pda/index.htm President's Design Awards] the nation's highest accolade, for their significant achievements and contributions to design. * B.Bike X PHUNK * BMW X PHUNK * Brain Magazine X PHUNK * Cappellini X PHUNK * Coca-Cola X PHUNK * Creative Review X PHUNK * Deutsche Bank X PHUNK * Gallery LVS X PHUNK * G-shock X PHUNK * Harpers Bazaar X PHUNK * HBO X PHUNK * Hermes X PHUNK * Hewlett Packard X PHUNK * HTC X PHUNK * Keiichi Tanaami X PHUNK * Levis X PHUNK * LTA X PHUNK * MTV X PHUNK * Nike X PHUNK * OCBC X PHUNK * Parco X PHUNK * Rolls Royce & SIA X PHUNK * Staple X PHUNK * STB X PHUNK * STPI X PHUNK * Tai Ping X PHUNK * Tiger Beer X PHUNK * The Rolling Stones X PHUNK * Timeout HK X PHUNK * Uniqlo X PHUNK * Wanderlust X PHUNK * Zouk X PHUNK

revision.comment: Alter: isbn. Add: title. Converted bare reference to cite template. Removed parameters. You can [[WP:UCB|use this bot]] yourself. [[WP:DBUG|Report bugs here]]. | [[WP:UCB|User-activated]]; [[Category:Critical theory]].
revision.text:
'''Post-postmodernism''' is a wide-ranging set of developments in [[critical theory]], [[philosophy]], [[architecture]], [[art]], [[literature]], and [[culture]] which are emerging from and reacting to [[postmodernism]]. Another similar recent term is [[metamodernism]]. ==Periodization== Most scholars would agree that [[modernism]] began around 1900 and continued on as the dominant cultural force in the intellectual circles of Western culture well into the mid-twentieth century.Compare, for example:
{{cite book|last=Childs|first=Peter|title=Modernism|publisher=[[Routledge]]|location=New York|year=2008|isbn=978-0-415-41544-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-v8SXB4l7kcC|page=18}}: "[modernism] is [...] primarily located in the years 1890-1930 [...]"
{{cite book|last=Armstrong|first=Tim|title=Modernism: A Cultural History|publisher=[[Polity Press]]|location=Cambridge|year=2005|isbn=978-0-7456-2983-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3k_C-1NZ4YYC&dq=isbn=0-7456-2983-0|page=24}}: "[modernism] can be defined as a series of international artistic movements in the period 1900-40 [...]." Like all eras, modernism encompasses many competing individual directions and is impossible to define as a discrete unity or totality. However, its chief general characteristics are often thought to include an emphasis on "radical aesthetics, technical experimentation, spatial or rhythmic, rather than chronological form, [and] self-conscious reflexiveness"{{cite book|last=Childs|first=Peter|title=Modernism|publisher=[[Routledge]]|location=New York|year=2008|isbn=978-0-415-41544-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-v8SXB4l7kcC|page=18}} as well as the search for authenticity in human relations, abstraction in art, and utopian striving. These characteristics are normally lacking in postmodernism or are treated as objects of irony. {{Postmodernism}} [[Postmodernism]] arose after World War II as a reaction to the perceived failings of modernism, whose radical artistic projects had come to be associated with [[totalitarianism]]Cf. Groys, Boris: ''The Total Art of Stalinism'', Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1992. or had been assimilated into mainstream culture. The basic features of what we now call postmodernism can be found as early as the 1940s, most notably in the work of [[Jorge Luis Borges]].See Barth, John: “[[The Literature of Exhaustion]].” ''The Atlantic Monthly'', August 1967, pp. 29-34. However, most scholars today would agree that postmodernism began to compete with modernism in the late 1950s and gained ascendancy over it in the 1960s.Cf., for example, Huyssen, Andreas: ''After the Great Divide. Modernism, Mass Culture, Postmodernism''. Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1986, p. 188. Since then, postmodernism has been a dominant, though not undisputed, force in art, literature, film, music, drama, architecture, history, and continental philosophy. Salient features of postmodernism are normally thought to include the ironic play with styles, citations and narrative levels,See Hutcheon, Linda: ''A Poetics of Postmodernism. History, Theory, Fiction''. New York: Routledge, 1988, pp. 3-21; McHale, Brian: ''Postmodern Fiction'', London: Methuen, 1987. a metaphysical skepticism or [[nihilism]] towards a "[[grand narrative]]" of Western culture,See Lyotard, Jean-François, ''The Postmodern Condition: A Report on Knowledge'', Minneapolis: University of Minneapolis Press 1984 a preference for the virtual at the expense of the real (or more accurately, a fundamental questioning of what 'the real' constitutes)See Baudrillard, Jean: “[[Simulacra and Simulation]]s.” In: ''Jean Baudrillard. Selected Writings''. Stanford: Stanford University Press 1988, pp. 166-184. and a "waning of affect"Jameson, Fredric: ''Postmodernism or, The Cultural Logic of Late Capitalism''. Durham: Duke University Press 1991, p. 16 on the part of the subject, who is caught up in the free interplay of virtual, endlessly reproducible signs inducing a state of consciousness similar to schizophrenia.Jameson, Fredric: ''Postmodernism or, The Cultural Logic of Late Capitalism''. Durham: Duke University Press 1991, pp. 26-27. Since the late 1990s there has been a small but growing feeling both in popular culture and in academia that postmodernism "has gone out of fashion."Potter, Garry and Lopez, Jose (eds.): ''After Postmodernism: An Introduction to Critical Realism''. London: The Athlone Press 2001, p. 4. However, there have been few formal attempts to define and name the era succeeding postmodernism, and none of the proposed designations has yet become part of mainstream usage. ==Definitions== Consensus on what constitutes an era can not be easily achieved while that era is still in its early stages. However, a common theme of current attempts to define post-postmodernism is emerging as one where faith, trust, dialogue, performance, and sincerity can work to transcend postmodern [[irony]]. The following definitions, which vary widely in depth, focus, and scope, are listed in the chronological order of their appearance. ===Turner's ''post-postmodernism''=== In 1995, the landscape architect and urban planner [[Tom Turner]] issued a book-length call for a post-postmodern turn in urban planning.''City as Landscape: A Post Post-modern View of Design and Planning'', (Taylor & Francis: London 1995). Turner criticizes the postmodern credo of “anything goes” and suggests that “the built environment professions are witnessing the gradual dawn of a post-Postmodernism that seeks to temper reason with faith.”''City as Landscape: A Post Post-modern View of Design and Planning'', (Taylor & Francis: London 1995), p. 9. In particular, Turner argues for the use of timeless organic and geometrical patterns in urban planning. As sources of such patterns he cites, among others, the Taoist-influenced work of the American architect [[Christopher Alexander]], [[gestalt psychology]] and the [[Psychoanalysis|psychoanalyst]] [[Carl Jung]]’s concept of [[Jungian archetypes|archetypes]]. Regarding terminology, Turner urges us to “embrace post-Postmodernism – and pray for a better name.”''City as Landscape: A Post Post-modern View of Design and Planning'', (Taylor & Francis: London 1995), p. 10; see also a summary of the book at [http://www.gardenvisit.com/history_theory/library_online_ebooks/architecture_city_as_landscape] ===Epstein's ''trans-postmodernism''=== In his 1999 book on [[Russian postmodernism]] the Russian-American Slavist [[Mikhail Epstein]] suggested that postmodernism “is […] part of a much larger historical formation,” which he calls “[[postmodernity]].”Epstein, Mikhail; Genis, Alexander; Vladiv-Glover, Slobodanka. ''Russian Postmodernism. New Perspectives on Post-Soviet Culture''. Berghahn Books: New York, 1999, p. 467. Epstein believes that postmodernist aesthetics will eventually become entirely conventional and provide the foundation for a new, non-ironic kind of poetry, which he describes using the prefix "[[:wikt:trans-|trans-]]": {{quote|In considering the names that might possibly be used to designate the new era following "postmodernism," one finds that the prefix "trans" stands out in a special way. The last third of the 20th century developed under the sign of "post," which signalled the demise of such concepts of modernity as "truth" and "objectivity," "soul" and "subjectivity," "utopia" and "ideality," "primary origin" and "originality," "sincerity" and "sentimentality." All of these concepts are now being reborn in the form of "trans-subjectivity," "trans-idealism," "trans-utopianism," "trans-originality," "trans-lyricism," "trans-sentimentality" etc.{{cite web | url=http://www.focusing.org/apm_papers/epstein.html | title=Epstein (specific) - the Place of Postmodernism in Postmodernity}}}} As an example Epstein cites the work of the contemporary Russian poet [[Timur Kibirov]].Epstein, Mikhail; Genis, Alexander; Vladiv-Glover, Slobodanka. ''Russian Postmodernism. New Perspectives on Post-Soviet Culture''. Berghahn Books: New York, 1999, pp. 457-460 ===Gans' ''post-millennialism''=== The term ''post-millennialism'' was introduced in 2000 by the American cultural theorist [[Eric Gans]]{{Cite journal | last = Gans | first = Eric | authorlink = Eric Gans | title = The Post-Millennial Age | journal = Anthropoetics | volume = 209 | date = June 3, 2000 | url = http://www.anthropoetics.ucla.edu/views/vw209/ | accessdate = {{date|2011-06-17|mdy}}}} to describe the era after postmodernism in ethical and socio-political terms. Gans associates postmodernism closely with "victimary thinking," which he defines as being based on a non-negotiable ethical opposition between perpetrators and victims arising out of the experience of [[Auschwitz]] and [[Hiroshima]]. In Gans's view, the ethics of postmodernism is derived from identifying with the peripheral victim and disdaining the utopian center occupied by the perpetrator. Postmodernism in this sense is marked by a victimary politics that is productive in its opposition to modernist utopianism and totalitarianism but unproductive in its resentment of capitalism and liberal democracy, which he sees as the long-term agents of global reconciliation. In contrast to postmodernism, post-millennialism is distinguished by the rejection of victimary thinking and a turn to "non-victimary dialogue"{{Cite journal | last = Gans | first = Eric | authorlink = Eric Gans | title = Victimary Thinking Forever? | journal = Anthropoetics | volume = 230 | date = March 31, 2001 | url = http://www.anthropoetics.ucla.edu/views/vw230.htm | accessdate = {{date|2011-06-17|mdy}}}} that will "diminish […] the amount of resentment in the world."{{Cite journal | last = Gans | first = Eric | authorlink = Eric Gans | title = Moral Heroism | journal = Anthropoetics | volume = 237 | date = June 9, 2001 | url = http://www.anthropoetics.ucla.edu/views/vw237.htm | accessdate = {{date|2011-06-17|mdy}}}} Gans has developed the notion of post-millennialism further in many of his internet ''Chronicles of Love and Resentment''{{Cite web | last = Gans | first = Eric | authorlink = Eric Gans | title = Chronicles of Love and Resentment | work = Anthropoetics | publisher = [[University of California, Los Angeles]] | date = | url = http://www.anthropoetics.ucla.edu/views/Chronicles_home.cfm | accessdate = {{date|2011-06-17|mdy}} }}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} and the term is allied closely with his theory of [[generative anthropology]] and his scenic concept of history.For more on both see Gans, Eric: ''Originary Thinking: Elements of Generative Anthropology''. Stanford, California: Stanford University Press 1993. ===Kirby's ''pseudo-modernism'' or ''digimodernism''=== In his 2006 paper [[The Death of Postmodernism and Beyond]], the British scholar [[Alan Kirby (writer)|Alan Kirby]] formulated a socio-cultural assessment of post-postmodernism that he calls “pseudo-modernism.”{{Cite journal | last = Kirby | first = Alan | authorlink = Alan Kirby (writer)| title = The Death of Postmodernism And Beyond | journal = Philosophy Now | volume = | issue = 58 | date = November–December 2006 | language = | url = http://www.philosophynow.org/issue58/58kirby.htm | accessdate = {{date|2011-06-17|mdy}}}} Kirby associates pseudo-modernism with the triteness and shallowness resulting from the instantaneous, direct, and superficial participation in culture made possible by the internet, mobile phones, interactive television and similar means: "In pseudo-modernism one phones, clicks, presses, surfs, chooses, moves, downloads." Pseudo-modernism's "typical intellectual states" are furthermore described as being "[[ignorance]], [[fanaticism]] and [[anxiety]]" and it is said to produce a "trance-like state" in those participating in it. The net result of this media-induced shallowness and instantaneous participation in trivial events is a "silent autism" superseding "the neurosis of modernism and the narcissism of postmodernism." Kirby sees no aesthetically valuable works coming out of "pseudo-modernism." As examples of its triteness he cites reality TV, interactive news programs, "the drivel found […] on some [[wikipedia|Wikipedia pages]]", docu-soaps, and the essayistic cinema of [[Michael Moore]] or [[Morgan Spurlock]]. In a book published in September 2009 titled ''Digimodernism: How New Technologies Dismantle the Postmodern and Reconfigure our Culture'', Kirby developed further and nuanced his views on culture and textuality in the aftermath of [[postmodernism]]. ===Vermeulen and van den Akker's ''metamodernism''=== In 2010 the cultural theorists Timotheus Vermeulen and Robin van den Akker introduced the term [[metamodernism]] Vermeulen, Timotheus and Robin van den Akker. "[http://aestheticsandculture.net/index.php/jac/article/view/5677/6304 Notes on metamodernism]", ''Journal of Aesthetics and Culture" 2010. as an intervention in the post-postmodernism debate. In their article 'Notes on metamodernism' they assert that the 2000s are characterized by the emergence of a sensibility that oscillates between, and must be situated beyond, modern positions and postmodern strategies. As examples of the metamodern sensibility Vermeulen and van den Akker cite the 'informed naivety', 'pragmatic idealism' and 'moderate fanaticism' of the various cultural responses to, among others, climate change, the financial crisis, and (geo)political instability. The prefix 'meta' here refers not to some reflective stance or repeated rumination, but to Plato's ''[[metaxy]]'', which intends a movement between opposite poles as well as beyond.{{cite web | url=http://www.metamodernism.com/2010/10/14/what-meta-means-and-does-not-mean/ | title=What meta means and does not mean}} ==See also== * [[Altermodern]] * [[Dogme 95]] * [[Excessivism]] * [[Integral theory (Ken Wilber)]] * [[Kitsch movement]] * [[Maximalism]] * [[Metamodernism]] * [[Neo-minimalism]] * [[New Puritans]] * [[New Sincerity]] * [[New Urbanism]] * [[Post-irony]] * [[Pseudorealism]] * [[Radical Orthodoxy]] * [[Remodernism]] * [[Stuckism]] * ''[[The Death of Postmodernism and Beyond]]'' * [[Transmodernism]] ==References== {{reflist|26em}} ==External links== *[http://www.timeshighereducation.co.uk/story.asp?storycode=411731 Essay by Alan Kirby on theories of post-postmodernism] *[http://www.focusing.org/apm_papers/epstein.html Essay by Mikhail Epstein on The Place of Postmodernism in Postmodernity] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20130810001724/http://alanfkirby.com/Introduction.pdf Introduction to "Digimodernism: How New Technologies Dismantle the Postmodern and Reconfigure Our Culture" by Alan Kirby] *[http://www.prlog.org/10814800-patrick-jf-queres-new-novel-grognard-now-available-at-major-booksellers.html Post-postmodern novel by Patrick J. F. Quere] *[http://aestheticsandculture.net/index.php/jac/article/viewArticle/5677 notes on metamodernism] *[http://www.performatism.de Performatism.de (Resource site for performatism and theories of post-postmodernism)] {{Criticism of postmodernism}} [[Category:Metamodernism|*]] [[Category:Theories of aesthetics]] [[Category:Architectural theory]] [[Category:Art genres]] [[Category:Contemporary art]] [[Category:Contemporary philosophy]] [[Category:Critical theory]] [[Category:Criticism of postmodernism]] [[Category:Modernism]] [[Category:Modernist architecture]] [[Category:New Urbanism]] [[Category:Postmodernism]] [[Category:Postmodern architecture]] [[Category:21st century in the arts]]

[[File:Pratt Art Center printmaking 02A.jpg|thumb|Printmaking shop at Pratt]] [[File:Pratt Art Center hot glass 01.jpg|thumb|Hot glass (glassblowing) facility at Pratt]] '''Pratt Fine Arts Center''' is a non-profit arts education and resource center in the [[Squire Park, Seattle, Washington|Squire Park]] area of [[Seattle]]'s [[Central District, Seattle, Washington|Central District]]. The school now serves 3,200 students and 500 working artists.<ref name=history>"History", Pratt Fine Arts Center quarterly class schedule, Winter 2004, p.1.</ref>
Pratt was founded in 1976 by the Seattle Department of Parks and Recreation<ref name=history /> and named in honor of slain [[Civil and political rights|civil rights]] leader [[Edwin T. Pratt]].<ref name=Lasting>"A Lasting Tribute", Pratt Fine Arts Center quarterly class schedule, Winter 2004, p. 1.</ref> In 1982 it was turned over to a newly created [[501(c)(3)]] non-profit, [[City Art Works]].<ref name=history />
Pratt includes facilities for [[glassblowing]], [[lampworking]], [[glass beadmaking]], [[Lampworking|flameworked glass]], [[Metalworking|metal sculpture]], [[bronze]] [[casting]], [[stone carving]], [[jewelry]] and [[metalsmithing]], [[woodworking]], [[printmaking]], [[painting]] and [[drawing]].<ref name=history /> The Center has three buildings: the main building in [[Pratt Park (Seattle)|Pratt Park]] (also named after Edwin Pratt) and two additional buildings in the block immediately south of the park.<ref>[http://www.pratt.org/PRIMARY/aboutus.html Location] on the official Pratt website. Accessed 24 February 2007.</ref> The latter two were originally part of the adjacent now empty [[Wonder Bread]] bakery.<ref>Lynn Porter, "Wonder Bread site back on the market", ''Seattle Daily Journal of Commerce'', June 6, 2006 (?).</ref><!-- accessed at http://www.43places.com/entries/view/883381, clearly a copy. -->
Programs include adult and youth education (including free Saturday programs for youth), master artist intensives and visiting artist programs, and studio access programs for working artists.<ref>"Education Programs", Pratt Fine Arts Center quarterly class schedule, Winter 2004, p.3.</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{commons category}} * [http://www.pratt.org/ Official site] * Kristin Dizon, [http://www.seattlepi.com/visualart/259995_prattglass20.html Boys with serious behavioral problems find a creative outlet in glass class], ''Seattle Post-Intelligencer'', February 20, 2006
[[Category:Schools in Seattle]] [[Category:Art schools in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 1976]] [[Category:Art galleries in Washington (state)]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Seattle]] [[Category:Central District, Seattle]]

{{EngvarB|date=August 2014}} {{BLP sources|date=January 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Sadie Frost | image = | caption = | birth_name = Sadie Liza Vaughan | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1965|6|19}} | birth_place = [[Islington]], [[London]], England | home_town = [[Ashton-under-Lyne]], [[Tameside]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Gary Kemp]]|1988|1995|end=div}}
{{marriage|[[Jude Law]]|1997|2003|end=div}} | parents = [[David Vaughan (artist)|David Vaughan]]
Mary Davidson | children = 4, including [[Iris Law]] | occupation = Actress | years_active = 1979–present }} '''Sadie Liza Frost''' (born 19 June 1965){{cn|date=October 2018}} is an English actress, producer and fashion designer, who ran fashion label [[Frost French]] (until its closure in 2011) and a film production company (Blonde to Black Pictures). ==Early life== Frost was born in [[Islington]], north London, to [[psychedelic art|psychedelic]] artist [[David Vaughan (artist)|David Vaughan]], who worked for [[the Beatles]], and his then-16-year-old muse, actress Mary Davidson.[http://women.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/women/celebrity/article2245713.ece Survivor: Sadie Frost] Sunday Times – 19 August 2007 She has described her childhood as a "chaotic but positive experience," as she was born in [[Islington]] but spent much of her youth in [[Ashton-under-Lyne]], [[Lancashire]], after her parents separated. Her parents had six relationships between them, which gave her four sisters and five brothers, including fellow actresses [[Holly Davidson]] and Jade Davidson; primary school teacher Jessi Frost, brothers called Gabriel Jupiter and Tobias Vaughan; and a sister named Sunshine Purple Tara Velvet.[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1285/is_n5_v25/ai_16869723 Frost's bite – interview with actress Sadie Frost] 1995 Brant Publications, Inc. {{Dead link|date=October 2010}} ==Career== {{BLP sources section|date=January 2015}} Frost appeared in a [[Jelly Tots]] advertisement in 1968 at age three and appeared with [[Morecambe and Wise]] in 1970 at age five. She attained a scholarship to the [[Italia Conti Academy]], but after an early [[eating disorder]],[http://www.femalefirst.co.uk/entertainment/Sadie+Frost-16212.html Sadie Frost Admits To Eating Disorder] Tatler/Femaleifrst.co.uk – 7 April 2006 she gave up acting at 13 and attended [[Hampstead School]] instead.[http://film.guardian.co.uk/Feature_Story/feature_story/0,,68709,00.html The questionnaire: Sadie Frost] ''The Guardian'' – 20 February 1999 On graduation{{when|date=January 2015}}, she left home to escape her parents, and in 1984, at age 19, she appeared in the play ''Mumbo Jumbo'' at the [[Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester|Royal Exchange Theatre]], Manchester, directed by [[Nicholas Hytner]].{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} As an actress, Frost has performed in ''[[Press Gang]]'' and ''[[Casualty (TV series)|Casualty]]''.[http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4158/is_20000206/ai_n14287713 Why are they famous: Sadie Frost] ''The Independent'' – 6 February 2000 Her first film role was in ''[[Empire State (1987 film)|Empire State]]'' (1987), although her most memorable{{opinion|date=January 2015}} film appearance is as [[vampire]] [[Lucy Westenra]] in [[Francis Ford Coppola]]'s ''[[Bram Stoker's Dracula]]'' (1992). She earned her living mainly through appearing in music videos, including for [[Pulp (band)|Pulp]]'s song "[[Common People (song)|Common People]]", [[Planet Perfecto]] featuring [[Grace (band)|Grace]]'s "Not Over Yet '99", and various productions for [[Spandau Ballet]], where she met first husband [[Gary Kemp]]. Frost and Kemp appeared together in the film ''[[The Krays (film)|The Krays]]'' (1990). They appeared in two more films together. One of these films, ''[[Magic Hunter]]'' (1994), required them to participate in a love scene, although they were separated at the time.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} Frost took a role opposite [[Jude Law]] in [[Paul W. S. Anderson]]'s directorial debut ''[[Shopping (1994 film)|Shopping]]''. After marrying Law and having three children with him, she cut down on her acting commitments in the late 1990s, and moved into producing and co-founding the production company [[Natural Nylon]].{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} In 1999, Frost co-founded the fashion label [[Frost French]] with her friend Jemima French. The label started in lingerie and expanded into clothing collections. Frost French won ''[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]''{{'}}s Designers of the Year Award 2004. In 2004, she wrote, presented, and produced a short-lived series ''What Sadie did next...'' for [[E4 (channel)|E4]], and in 2005 appeared in ''Eating with...Sadie Frost'' on [[BBC Two|BBC2]]. In March 2006, Frost flew to South Africa to part-fund an orphanage for the ''Homes of Hope'' project. In September 2006, aged 41, she posed nude for Canadian photographer [[Bryan Adams]] for a [[PETA]] anti-fur advert to coincide with [[London Fashion Week]].{{cite web |url=https://www.peta.org.uk/media/news-releases/sadie-frosts-naked-ambition-for-animals/ |title=Sadie Frost’S Naked Ambition For Animals |last= |first= |date=19 September 2006 |website=PETA UK |publisher= |access-date=10 February 2018 |quote=Sadie Unveils Sexy Ad Shot By Bryan Adams During London Fashion Week}} In 2009, she made her [[West End Theatre|West End]] debut in ''Touched ... For the Very First Time'', a new one-woman show by [[Zoë Lewis]], directed by Douglas Rintoul and produced by [[Imogen Lloyd Webber]].{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} In January 2010, Frost starred in the play ''Fool for Love'' alongside [[Carl Barat]], formerly of [[The Libertines]]. The play showed at the [[Riverside Studios]] theatre.Brown, G. (2010, Feb 07). A polished pout, but sadie isn't fooling us. ''Mail on Sunday'' Retrieved from https://search.proquest.com/docview/329134306?accountid=15830 ==Personal life== In 1981, when 16 and dancing in a music video, Frost met [[Spandau Ballet]]'s Gary Kemp. They married when she was 22, shortly before her 23rd birthday, on 7 May 1988. Their son, Finlay, was born in 1990. Frost and Kemp were married for five years and then separated, finally divorcing on 19 August 1995.Jonathan Bernstein, [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1285/is_n5_v25/ai_16869723/pg_2?tag=content;col1 ''Frost's bite''], BNET, Arts Publications, interview, May 1995 Frost met Jude Law during the work on the film ''Shopping''. They married on 2 September 1997 and had three children: a son born in 1996; a daughter called [[Iris Law]]; and another son born in 2002. Frost and Law divorced on 29 October 2003.Silverman, Stephen M. [http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,627145,00.html Jude Law, Sadie Frost Divorce Official] ''People'' magazine – 29 October 2003 Frost named model [[Kate Moss]] as Iris's godmother and [[BBC Radio 1]] [[deejay]] [[Nick Grimshaw]] as Rudy's godfather.{{Cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/sadie-frost-jude-laws-youngest-4898375|title=Sadie Frost and Jude Law’s youngest children are the PERFECT mix of their DNA: Mum shares holiday snaps|last=Strang|first=Fay|date=2014-12-31|work=mirror|access-date=2018-09-28}} She is a vegetarian.{{cite web|url=http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/life/food-drink/sadie-frost-vegetarian-507329#RikeLQmB184kEcJP.99|title=Sadie Frost opens up about how vegetarianism changed her life|date=19 May 2017|magazine=Marie Claire}} == Filmography == {|class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{for|the painting from the same artist|St. Jerome in His Study (Dürer, 1521)}} {{Infobox Artwork |image_file=Dürer-Hieronymus-im-Gehäus.jpg |image_size=300px |title=Saint Jerome in His Study |artist=Albrecht Dürer |type=[[engraving]] |year=1514 |height_metric=24.7 |width_metric=18.8 |metric_unit=cm |imperial_unit=in }} '''''Saint Jerome in His Study''''' ({{lang-de|Der heilige Hieronymus im Gehäus}}) is an [[engraving]] of 1514 by the German artist [[Albrecht Dürer]]. Saint [[Jerome]] is shown sitting behind his desk, engrossed in work. The table, on the corner of which is a cross, is typical of the [[Renaissance]]. An imaginary line from Jerome's head passing through the cross would arrive at the skull on the window ledge, as if contrasting death and the [[Resurrection]]. The lion in the foreground is part of the traditional [[iconography]] of St. Jerome, and near it is a sleeping dog, an animal found frequently in Dürer's works, symbolizing loyalty. Both creatures are part of Jerome's story in the ''[[Golden Legend]]'' (c. 1260), which contained fanciful [[Hagiography|hagiographies]] of saints. ''St. Jerome in His Study'' is often considered as part of a group of three Dürer engravings, the other two being the well-known ''[[Melencolia I]]'' (1514) and ''[[Knight, Death and the Devil]]'' (1513). Together they have been viewed as representing the three spheres of activity recognized in medieval times: ''Knight, Death, and the Devil'' belongs to the moral sphere and the "active life"; ''Melencolia I'' represents the intellectual; and ''St. Jerome'' the theological and contemplative life. The composition is intimate, but the viewer has difficulty locating himself in relation to the picture's space. Thomas Puttfarken suggests that while the scene is very close to the observer, Dürer did not intend the viewer to feel present: "the intimacy is not ours, but the saint's as he is engrossed in study and meditation" (94). Art historian [[Erwin Panofsky]] comments on the perspective:
The position of the sight point, quite far off centre, strengthens the impression of a representation determined not by the objective law of the architecture but by the subjective standpoint of the spectator who is just entering – a representation which owes to precisely this perspective arrangement a large part of its peculiarly 'intimate' effect. (Qtd. in Puttfarken, 94)
==Jonah and the gourd vine== Using a dried [[gourd]] hanging from the rafters, Dürer memorializes Jerome's [[courage]], in the face of a long brewing [[Philology|philological]] controversyPeter W. Parshall, "Albrecht Dürer's Saint Jerome in his Study: A Philological Reference," The Art Bulletin 53 (September 1971), pp. 303-5, [http://www.oberlin.edu/amam/DurerSt.Jerome.htm] with [[St. Augustine]] in his preferencehttp://www.newadvent.org/bible/jon004.htm Chapter 4 of the Book of Jonah in concurrent Greek:English:Latin versions for Greek over Latin nomenclature for the fast-growing plant known in Hebrew as קיקיון (qiyqayown) encountered only this once, in the [[Book of Jonah]]. The [[Old Testament]] text closes abruptly ({{bibleverse|Jonah||4}}) with an epistolary warningCatholic Encyclopedia article titled '''Jonah''' http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/08497b.htm based on the [[emblem]]atic trope of a fast-growing vine present in Persian narratives, and popularized widely in certain collections of [[Aesop's fables]] such as [[The Gourd and the Palm-tree]]. Jerome elected to use '''[[Hedera]]''' (from the Greek, meaning ivy) over the more common Latin '''[[cucurbita]]''' from which the related English plant name ''cucumber'' is derived, perhaps to avoid confusion while making a more perfect analogy to the typology of Christ [[:it:File:Christ the True Vine icon (Athens, 16th century).jpg|''"I am the Vine you are the branches"'']]. In fact Augustine's view had already prevailed by Dürer's time. == References == {{Reflist}} ==Sources== * Puttfarken, Thomas (2000). ''The Discovery of Pictorial Composition: Theories of Visual Order in Painting 1400–1800.'' New Haven & London: [[Yale University Press]]. {{ISBN|0-300-08156-1}}. {{Dürer}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saint Jerome in His Study (Durer)}} [[Category:Prints by Albrecht Dürer]] [[Category:1514 works]] [[Category:16th-century engravings]] [[Category:Paintings of Saint Jerome|Durer]] [[Category:Lions in art]] [[Category:Dogs in art]] [[Category:Books in art]] [[Category:Skulls in art]]

{{unreferenced|date=October 2016}} '''Scala Regia''' ({{IPA-la|ˈskaːla ˈreːɡia}}; {{lang-en|Royal Staircase}}) is a term referring to a number of majestic entrance staircases, including:
* The [[Scala Regia (Vatican)|Scala Regia]] of the [[Vatican city|Vatican]], a flight of steps designed by [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]] (1663–1666) to connect the Vatican Palace to [[St. Peter's Basilica]]. * Main staircase of [[Villa Farnese]] at [[Caprarola]] * Entrance to [[Ducal Palace, Lucca|the Ducal Palace]] of [[Lucca]] * Entrance to House of Lords, Westminster, United Kingdom
Other staircase entrances include the Scala d'Oro in [[Venice]].
[[Category:Renaissance architecture]] [[Category:Baroque architectural features]]

{{italic title}} '''''Supervising Women Workers''''' was a short social guidance film produced by the [[United States|US]] [[Office of Education]] and aimed at male foremen who now had to supervise women for war work.
The film depicts the social and gender relations and attitudes of its time. It notes that most of the women had never been in industry before, and were unfamiliar with the terminology and mores common to the plant. Each thing had to be broken down and explained in detail. The film also reminds men that women of the day have been at work in things like knitting and sewing, and that these skills could be appropriated for war work. In a short vignette the foreman returns home to his wife, complaining about all the women asking for time off. His wife then tells him she had to cook, clean, and take care of the children all day, at which point the foreman realizes that women really work two jobs, one in the factory and the other at home.
In another vignette a foremen gets into an argument about a woman not wearing a protective hat, and it is shown that he has to explain to her why the protective cap was necessary. Finally, there are four basic rules to supervising women workers: *don't mix business with pleasure *remember that women are awfully jealous of each other *avoid undue familiarity *women are more sensitive than men.
== See also == [[List of Allied propaganda films of World War II]]
== External links == *[https://archive.org/details/Supervis1944 complete film at archive.org]

{{italic title}} [[File:Peter Paul Rubens 082.jpg|thumb]] '''''The Defeat of Sennacherib''''' is a painting by [[Peter Paul Rubens]], now in the [[Alte Pinakothek]] in [[Munich]], produced between around 1612 and 1614. It shows the defeat of the army of [[Sennacherib]] by an angel, as described in the Old Testament. It is a pendant to ''[[The Conversion of Saint Paul (Rubens)|The Conversion of Saint Paul]]'', now in the [[Courtauld Gallery]] in London.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/arts/yourpaintings/paintings/conversion-of-saint-paul-207428|title=Conversion of Saint Paul|accessdate=January 27, 2014|publisher=[[BBC]]}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *https://web.archive.org/web/20150104182214/http://www.pinakothek.de/node/46983
{{Rubens}}
